author: {'steamid': '76561198003495525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 7550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1917, 'last_played': 1604999214}
review:
ВНИМАНИЕ: Разработка игры заморожена.
ATTENTION: Antihero Studios continued the game development in July 2020 but since then not much news. Development has stopped.
https://steamcommunity.com/games/509580/announcements/detail/2736451422509046763

Красивая карточная PvE игра с кооперативом. 
Для любителя Средиземья здесь есть все - фирменная атмосфера с реверансами в сторону кинотрилогии, нарядная стилистика, неплохие арты (тут как раз без привязки к питерджексоновскому творению).
В игре пока нет русского языка, и если с правилами разобраться можно, то читать/слушать литературные вставки, которые написаны "под Толкиена", вряд ли получится.

Опишу игровой процесс: Вы собираете колоду из 3 героев и 30 вспомогательных карт: юниты поддержки, предметы (которые можно повесить на героев или юнитов) и события (ивенты с разными эффектами, контрспеллы). Она одна на все задание.
Играете против ИИ Саурона с колодой "темных сил".
Каждый раунд получаете очки на то, чтобы сыграть карты, пришедшие в руку, а также распоряжаетесь уже находящимися в игре персонажами.
Они имеют три параметра: очки атаки, очки выполнения целей и здоровье. 
Очки выполнения целей - по сути та же "атака", только для другого типа карт соперника, которые каждый ход приносят тот или иной эффект.
Задание состоит из нескольких боев, с перерывами на сюжет, представленный в форме коротеньких аудио-рассказов. Каждый новый раунд для вас начинается с состояния, на котором вы закончили предыдущий. Интересная механика, так как можно задержаться в раунде, который уже вроде бы выигран, чтобы лучше подготовиться к следующему, а в результате напороться на неприятности.
Есть шкала "угроза", которая заполняется и уменьшается в зависимости от разных действий, она гонит вас вперед по раундам и влияет на итоговый счет. Необходимо поддерживать баланс между уроном, отхилом, сдерживанием угрозы, что является основным фактором при создании колоды.
Присутствует кооперативный режим - задания длятся дольше, что при низкой динамике процесса может заставить заскучать.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314000103', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1587265826}
review:
I have the table-top version of this card game and I love it.  When I found out they were doing a video game version I was very excited.  This takes the game I love and makes it a thousand times better.  The voice acting, narration, and animations are absolutely wonderful!

Right now there are indeed a few bugs.  Some slight locking up and freezing, the card clicks don't register at times, that sort of thing.  But nothing is game breaking and obviously the game is still being worked upon.  I think this game will really be something special.

It is refreshing, as is the table top version, to have a game that is single player or cooperative.  Typically, card games are against another player or an A.I. player.  I love the quest format and working together.  I'll be very curious to see how multiplayer functions down the road.

This is a relaxing game of skill.  It has a very high learning curve.  It is definitely not something you can master in a short time.  I cannot wait to see what is in store for us players!  This game is tops on my card games along with Gwent.  Both are fantastic games in the art, voice, and music department.

I certainly suggest giving this game a go!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999364095', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1149, 'last_played': 1635203334}
review:
Is it the same thing as the physical game? No.
Is it still challenging and enjoyable? Yes.

I sat on this for a while, but have been playing more the last couple days, and I'm enjoying it quite a bit indeed. This stands on its own as a fun time full of puzzling challenges to overcome. At the time of this review I am working on the 4th quest, and have the first three pretty much on farm with the two decks I've made so far. There was indeed a learning curve, but it seems that most of that was learning to actually defend and getting the exploration bonuses is very important. It literally just started to click with me after a few games yesterday and today, and I was a millimeter from completing quest 4 as well, a very exciting 2nd attempt. I'll get it soon enough, I suppose. 

UPDATE: After a nice sleep, cleared The Shadow's Reach campaign, chapter 4 is definitely the challenging part there. Very fun all around.

I also enjoy the bonus for clearing each quest with each hero, in that it encourages more deckbuilding. (And gets me more cards.)

A great time solo, and I'm looking forward to the co-op, as well as more adventures.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089832553', 'num_games_owned': 452, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1699137401}
review:
I rarely write reviews of games let alone for Early Access games. This is an exception however. This is the card game I have wanted all my life. Having spent countless hours playing Hearthstone, PTCGO, and dabbling in Magic, I'm no stranger to the boost pack grind. It sucks. This game takes care of that by using a Living Card Game model.

Gameplay mechanics are complex and deep, and while the card pool is currently not large, it has a good number of mechanics that are unique, interesting, and fun. I've yet to play the paper version, which is reportedly different.

The art is great and I was very happy to see it not simple clones of the movie depictions of these characters, yet they have a deep respect and understanding for the source material. The backgrounds are beautifully crafted and combined with the music and voice acting. 

It is challenging but not as impossible as some have claimed. If you want a game you can face roll your way through, look elsewhere but if what you want is an enjoyable, engaging card game with interesting mechanics and reams of atmosphere look no further.

This game is in early access and so is far from perfect in execution. There are a few quality of life improvements that would make the game nicer, and I can't wait for more content to be added. The tutorial does give you all the information you need but throws it at you rather quickly which makes it hard to absorb. This is probably the source of most people's troubles with the game.

The developers actually listen to their community and make changes, such as the move away from the f2p model. They hae a huge repect for the source material and want to create something actually fun to play not just a shallow cash grab. A++++ will buy again as soon as it comes out on switch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986317468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1552042312}
review:
Hands down the hardest card game I've played. Which is an excellent thing! With over 20 yrs experience in MTG and other various CCG's this game has required me to awaken from the slumber of that which is the easy mode in most CCG's and actually THINK about what I want to do and what I want to do 3 turns from now. This game is merciless and will give no quarter for a misplayed card/abilty. 

Thankyou Dev's for recreating this classic LCG and causing me to increase my vocabulary of profanity that I readily employ against the servants of the darklord.

That being said, you are forced to play lore.  Has anyone found a way to play without green? review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198007233194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 3511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1678284173}
review:
EDIT (updated Dec 2019):

This review was first written during EA, and is now updated to latest events.

At release game texts and cards were not presented well. Text rendering was especially bad. Things have been going better since. There was a second problem with the price of expansions; this problem was removed in Dec 2019.

You now have three free campaigns/expansions (meaning 15 adventures, each of several steps) + 3 separate adventures + the Galadriel procedural / replayable mission.

This is a lot of content! and every adventure has specific rewards you can look for, and each can also be played and won with every hero for more rewards.

Time to gift the game to friends and play coop :D


EDIT 2:
I did gift it and played coop!

The coop game is a bliss.
Story mode is much too easy, and Challenge mode is really hard; players should still play Challenge on coop, in my opinion, for maximum pleasure.


EDIT 3:
Please note that since a change of developers there has been no update, except a drastic (and worse imo) change in game menu. The new developers had immense ambitions for the game but we had no news since some time. But the title as it stands still gives access to a lot of gameplay!

======================================

I will try in this review to be comprehensive.

Other reviews kept me away from this game for months and I believe it is important for you now to determine the "truth" and to know if this LCG is a great game or not, and if it is a game for you.


[h1]What kept me away for so long[/h1]

From screenshots and reviews there was one main thing that was horrifying to me:
I thought that the game was dumbed down!
That it was looking like some sort of Hearthstone clone!
That the concepts and mechanics of the game were transformed into their simplest version!

Others were mentioning also the price model in their review: not enough Valor received, purchases too expensive, too much grinding etc.

And the elephant in the room: unfortunately it's a game inspired by the physical card game and reproducing its spirit, but not a digital full remake of it.

[h1]What I found[/h1]

To be honest what I found instead was a great gem of a game: with much care and passion given to the narrative, to voice overs, to illustrations, to keep you in the world of Middle Earth; and even more to the mechanics of the game.

What is still true is that you cannot consider this game like a 100 percent faithful port (or even a 80 % one).

You must consider this game like a new game of its own.

But contrary to the impressions I received so far, it still deserves to call itself LOTR:LCG and had an impressive way of putting together the concepts & mechanics in ways that are still very deep, faithful and quite adapted to a computer game.


[h1]About Difficulty and Duration[/h1]

I took the game with the base Shire Pack and customized my own deck from it; no special pack used and no valor card purchased. It took me several attempts and 3 hours of calm, non-rushed play, to beat the first quest at Normal Difficulty.

Every adventure is a series of quests. We now have 3 campaigns of 5 quests each, and 3 encounters. I estimate it needs 10-40 hours of gameplay in order to beat one campaign and one encounter, and we have 3 times that now. 

To me, it is satisfying. The game is challenging and a real pleasure to play. More about pros and cons below, but I would disagree with opinions about the game being: too easy or too short. What you get here is a solo content above anything provided so far by card games (even TES Legends) and I think it is important to have proper information and understand what you currently get.

I think the mention about it being "too hard" is because it's hard to receive max Valor for a quest.

[h1]About the Price Model[/h1]

The price model has been 'fixed' and improved during EA. Although a bit problematic at release (ie. expansions) it is now almost entirely free. 

You can earn as much Valor (now has another name!) as possible by being successful at Quests, and then spend it for cards. Purchasing a rare powerful card from the Valor Store costs 1500, and a successful Quest gives you 2000 if you played new heroes (a hero nets you a +500 bonus when he beats it for the first time).

An adventure of 5 quests should give you around 10 000 Valor, and you can even max that above it.


[h1]About the Narrative[/h1]

The narrative was the best surprise I had. You have large illustrations, a voiced narrator, new voice overs from Gollum, Dwarves, Elves, Hobbits, and it's of top notch movie-quality; and writing is even better, with much style and middle earth ominous writing style.

Note that I tested the game in english language, as I had doubts about translations quality.

Some card illustrations are absolutely great. However cards suffer from the invasive and colorful template with symbols for Threat, Combat, Willpower and Health.


[h1]About Mechanics[/h1]

My last point will be about the mechanics. I was worried about that a lot before trying the game.

Heroes generate Threat at the beginning of an adventure. You must not reach 50 Threat, and at different thresholds Sauron can unleash a new event. All Threat powers are relatively powerful, as they should be. I disagree with opinions mentioning that you could put "all your most powerful heroes in your deck" and not "think about Threat", however that sounds true in "Story" difficulty (=easy mode) but not on "Challenge" difficulty (=normal mode).

I have been in situations where just one, two, or three points of Threat were the difference between victory or defeat just because of some event. However, players will certainly master Threat more and more, and players purchasing cards from the Valor Store will have an easier and easier experience over time, and will then be able to put powerful Heroes without any second thought; at least with first campaign ;)

Threat mechanics, in my opinion, was perfectly ported and balanced.

Heroes can generate Fate by using your action, and at certain thresholds can use it for one-time positive effects. These effects are different for every quest chapter.

For instance, in first chapter of first quest, I could use it to receive supplies (2 Fate), to exhaust enemies (4 Fate), or to have Gloin join the part (7 Fate). The Fate mechanics was perfectly balanced too in my experience, as I was forced sometimes to rush and forget about it and other times was able to use it.

Activating Fate or Threat does not take your turn, but everything else does: attacking, playing one card, or using a card power.

You take an action, then your enemy does the same, until you cannot play any action or card. 

You can attack creatures with Combat, and locations/events with Willpower.

Any unit can decide to guard. Guarding is an action which takes your turn and your guard unit will be exhausted in one attack. Guarding is the only way to deal damage when defending. It is well thought and different from other games.

When you play an adventure, you play it like a campaign, keeping your card hand, resources, cards in play etc from one chapter to the next; deciding between rushing or not makes for great replayability and risky decision-making. 

I am satisfied by the mechanics of the game, deeper that what the screenshots hinted at me; developers if you read this, please use screenshots to hint at how deep the game is, how great the writing is!

A strong negative was (is still?) the current card collection. Not enough cards and the real drawback is that deck building is made much easier, but also less deep than in the original game. I hope that will be improved, and is currently the main negative I have to mention!

PS: I had no special network setup to do to play the game and no need to apply the network recommendations from store page.

But developers should make the game fullscreen by default at first launch, it was currently at EA and resized window has bad antialiasing on fonts/textures/etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052679671', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 4197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1010, 'last_played': 1704723277}
review:
I need to say something:

1. This is a very good game which needs more polish. But that can only happen if the developers do so. And this will happen if enough players play it. So give it a try and read the positive feedback for this game. Not the negative because:

2. The negative reviews here are: "This is not the living card game which I own" or: "The missions are very hard and you cant beat them even with buying the expensive pack".

Please guys, its inspired by the card game which already exists but its very nice and slightly different. And yeah its kinda hard but if you check the cards, built one or two decks and do some trial and error it will work. trust me ;). Soundtrack, gameplay, difficulty level and motivation all in one. And it isn`t a hearthstone clone! I swear!

PS: Its not pay to win. You get more Avatar pictures and stuff like that but the prices are horrific. Do yourself a favour and buy the starter pack. Its the cheapest and you get the whole experience. Thats the only negative thing I can say about this. 45€ for some more pictures and rare cards? Come on, Fantasy Flight, you can do better...
Wednesday the 09.01.2019 (European Time) we get a new Expansion...

author: {'steamid': '76561198269975465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1551358353}
review: I made a review regarding some bugs but it was my internet connectivity that was causing these issues so I removed it. After a few plays and progressing through the scenarios I can see a lot of positive things. I like the voice acting, music and general feel to the story but I have some issues with some design choices of terains, cards and characters. Right now I am waiting for multiplayer to judge the gameplay cause that is why I mostly bought it for. For the co- up. No interest of playing a digital live card game alone. I do it with Arkham Horror Lcg but I like the feel of tokens, cards and physical aspect of the game. I definetely recommend the game but I secretely wish it is gonna be much more in the future aesthetic wise. I backed with 27 euros, I wouldn't if I didn't believe in this game delivering. But please, I beg you. Less hearthstone feel to it and more LotR physical card boardgame feel to the design aspect of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007812404', 'num_games_owned': 1247, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1546549228}
review:
I understand that the LCG genre is an established thing in Board Games, and indeed, I have played a number of LCG brand and similair board games myself, and have thouroghly enjoyed myself, but this game runs the risk of being too niche and require too much experience to succeed. 

Having seen this on steam, I was quite excited, I loved Arkham Horror and was looking forward to playing whilst not having to slot everything back in to the box again! I am not very good at LCG's I freely admit, and card games in general seem to go over my head, rather frustratingly, but often I enjoy playing card games, because, whilst I can naively blame RNG on the draw of the deck, I at least feel like the game is remaining fresh, with small progress being made, even in defeat, so I feel like there is at least some movement, however, In this, the tutorial held your hand on a lovely relaxing meandering path only to drop you in to the firey pits of Mount Doom immeadiatly afterwards. The steep learning cliff was just unenjoyable, as, I do not know enough about the game to construct a deck, and for a noob, the starter deck seem frustratingly on the back foot. There are those out there who will be afficiandoes at LCG's who will stroll through no issues, but, that will not help cultivate a healthy player base. The acheivement statistics reflect this, with an incredible drop off after the initial Tutorial. It shows that interest is there, but there is little drive to continue playing if you are not already well versed in the game. I do hope that the game itself can be made a bit more 'newbie' friendly to act as an in into the LCG universe at large, but there is not enough gameplay to easily learn from. Instead you go from Day-Care, to Graduation exam in one level, and it results in coming up against a brick wall with little opportunity to improve.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991395877', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 5710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1615546374}
review:
This game has the depth, thematic value, and complexity of the physical LCG while substantially minimising the time required to deckbuild and play. Artwork and music are fantastic. Just like the physical LCG, you sometimes need to attempt quests multiple times with different decks to beat them -- but unlike the physical LCG, it's not such a massive timesink to build decks and play the quests. Once you do beat the quests, it is very satisfying! Highly recommended for fans of the physical LCG or Lord of the Rings in general!

2022 EDIT - Game appears to have been abandoned by Anti-Hero Studios (who took over from Fantasy Flight Interactive after they abandoned it). No communication at all from Anti-Hero Studios or Asmodee in a very long time. Not worth buying at full price if the game is not supported with new cards and new quests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005076292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1627440209}
review:
Awesome card game. Just as good as the board game since it cuts a lot of the setup and sloggy moments (and card sleeve costs).

Still challenging, every game feels like a close-call. Not a one for one game to the LCG but still feels and plays well.

Absolutely looking forward for more quests and cards and dwarves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030849172', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2888, 'last_played': 1603494055}
review:
I know some folks don’t want to read a long, meandering review, so I’ll abbreviate my experience thus far with this: I’ve found myself trying to learn how to use a fan made tabletop simulation of the tabletop version of this game because Asmodee Digital has committed to going in a direction with this game that will probably never "feel" right to me. This game lacks immersion and it lacks complexity, what I believe are the heart and soul which make the tabletop version so wonderful.

A longer summary:

I am a lifelong Tolkien fan who only recently discovered (and instantly fell in love with) The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game (also known as LOTR:LCG, the tabletop version). In addition to the core box, I own the entire Mirkwood cycle, as well as the Haradrim cycle. Much to the chagrin of my wife, I’ll probably be buying into as many cycles as Fantasy Flight Games reprints or releases. That said, it only made sense to jump into the Early Access of the digital version produced by Asmodee Digital.

Unfortunately, I have to ditto the assessment of many others who say that the digital game is only "okay" for now, or even just "meh," even at the relatively low $8 entry. There are a couple of major issues, in my opinion:

My first complaint, that I struggle to put into words, exactly, is stylistic. The digital version just doesn’t feel Middle-earth-y enough. I don’t know if this is because of Asmodee Digital’s choice of fontstyle not looking elfish or dwarfish enough to my eyes, or if it is because of the ridiculously fancy, lightsaber-esque lens flare effects whenever I hover my cursor over anything. Maybe, it is because of the bright primary color banners and icons on the cards. I don't know. I just know there’s just something terribly lacking in the immersion department. I love sitting in my cozy office, with my German Shepherd at my feet and a pipe clenched in my teeth, and sleeving the beautiful cards that come with the tabletop version. I love holding the cards under my reading lamp to admire the artwork, read the lore, and remind myself of the various effects the card brings to my decks. But in the digital version, none of the cards have lore and really very little in the way of complexity.

And this is really my main complaint. While Asmodee Digital could probably relatively easily add the missing lore and Middle-earth-ify the game a tad more, most of the elements of the tabletop edition which make it so fun, namely the mechanical depth, the nuances of deckbuilding, balancing the four resource pools, determining to quest or attack or defend, being careful to watch threat values, and the various wrinkles by way of planning out a hand and being encountered by shadow effects and the like, the developers have apparently determined NOT to add to the digital version of the game. I think this is a huge, huge mistake. I think most of the folks that invested in this Early Access title basically want a licensed, polished version of OCTGN, a fan-made tabletop simulation of the card game. What apparently a majority of us don't want (the game peaked at less than 30 players in the past 24 hours), is yet another Hearthstone -like game which, to quote other reviewers, is “distilled,” “watered-down,” “dumbed down,” “shallow,” and “soulless.” I think this lack of depth will be even more readily apparent once co-op is enabled.

I will continue to follow the game in its development, I'll piddle around with the new expansion packs (only if they are free), and I hope in time my review will reflect drastic changes in the direction that most of us fans of the tabeltop are hoping for... but right now, I’m afraid I can NOT recommend the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040978879', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1678569964}
review:
Got to meet a few of the folks working on this game at Gamehole Con and finally got to pick up the game after trying it out there.

Keeping in mind it's an early access game and it does still need some polish here and there it's a solid digital version of The Lord of the Rings Living Card Game. Mind you it's not a 1:1, but it's still highly enjoyable.

Make sure to go into the Settings and try the tutorial, even if you've played LotR:LCG tabletop before, there are enough changes that you'll want to know what is going on here, now the tutorial will not cover Deck Building at all, but it's pretty straight forward (Pick Heroes, pick cards based on those heroes). 

Pros:
 If you've played any digital card game before and like the theme of Lord of the Rings,  this is very easy to pick up and play.

Voice Acting is good. 

Artwork is great.

Few Cons I Have:
 The Scoring, I've had a few times where I feel like I've had great runs, cleared every location (both hazards and enemies), but because I ignored using Fate because of how my deck was built I'm penalized for it.

No "Are You Sure?" prompt when deleting a deck. 


All in all, I'd give this game a 7 out of 10, but could easily improve upon full release

author: {'steamid': '76561198359764054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2201, 'last_played': 1559205593}
review:
The first Living Card Game arrives on Steam, and after many months of developement and improvements (including the long-awaited autosave-feature) and the first DLC, the game starts to feel like the GOTY, that always lied within it...

At this stage of developement, the game is deep, complex and very beautiful, and i would rate it the best single-player or coop CCG experience (if playing on the hardest difficulty, and with all cards unlocked)...

It still is a bit low on content, if counting pure missions, but still, if you want to unlock all stuff (and there is plenty of), and master all missions on the highest difficulty, you will spend dozens of hours, and even after that, you may hunt for many achievements, try out different deck, or follow your own goals (f.e. beating the game on hard with mono-colored decks, which is a real challange!).

10/10 rings from my side, and cant wait to buy new content!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017952390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1641874913}
review:
I was a little disappointed at first when they revealed (almost a year ago now) that the game wasn't a complete digital recreation of the physical version. But now I'm glad this version can stand on its own. It's a lot of fun, even with the limited content in early access. I expected to get bored of playing the same quests over and over, but I keep coming back. I expect it to get even better as more cards and quests come out.

The devs do a great job of listening to feedback too. I'm glad this game is finding its footing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198349146593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1489, 'last_played': 1651609658}
review:
This is the first game that has prompted me to write a review in Steam. First of all, I have not encountered any of the glitches and bugs that some others have - for me, the game runs perfectly, there has been nothing wrong with playability, and the game is beautifully executed. As far as the first campaign goes, it has felt to me as good as a finished product. 

I love the tabletop Lord of the Rings LCG, and I knew before purchasing that this is not going to be an exact conversion of the tabletop game, which made me a little bit disappointed at first. But here's my most important two cents: Now I'm happy it is not the same game. In my opinion, this digital version keeps the core of the tabletop game, but with variations, different mechanics and new things to discover; for me, it hits the perfect balance of giving me an essentially new game, but still being unmistakably Lord of the Rings LCG. 

So far I've only used normal difficulty level, and yes, indeed the AI opponent is somewhat "dumb": it rarely makes optimal choices, and sometimes leaves actions unused. Anyway, the quests are still challenging enough, especially in the beginning, before getting a hang on the game. I don't feel that the AI hurts the feel of the game, either; orcs and spiders are not a very organized bunch, and it feels kind of suitable that their attacking is somewhat random. As for Sauron, I just imagine that his eye does not quite see everything. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032974226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1607864893}
review:
Never played the physical version of the game but i was really interested to try this when i saw it and will be buying the physical version because of this game.

At first i was playing this game like i would Hearthstone, but i quickly got punished for playing that way. After a bunch of revisits to my decks and playstyle it finally clicked and i was able to win far more consistently. 

The music is actually really good, the voiced acted original stories that acompany the gameplay are a welcome inclusion and really help with the immersion and atmosphere of the entire experience. The inclusion of co-op later on in development is something that im really excited about as well.

Its been super fun and i think anyone that is a fan of card games and lotr will get some enjoyment out of this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997071430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1585852249}
review:
This is not a bad game, but it is not a great game. This is a fill the void, sitting in the back seat or on the train game. Its one of those game that once you figure it out, it becomes pretty easy. There is not a tone of deck building yet which makes building decks for the most part all the same. 

I have played the tabletop LCG and it is leagues over this version. But really the games are very diffrent from each other. So it is pointless to compare them. 

Overall the gae is fun, its worth it but only as a time sink game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070650254', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 9883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7871, 'last_played': 1639280157}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970312961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1540569193}
review:
Unfortunately, this game is just not very fun when compared to the tabletop version. I've been a long-time player of the tabletop, which I absolutely adore, but this digital version is just too different and significantly dumbed down to be any real, long-term fun. I knew it was different going in, but after playing for 2 hours and seeing just how different I realised it's not for me.

They've really shot themselves in the foot with this game I feel. I can see what they were trying to do, appeal to some of the playerbase of Hearthstone who may also like LOTR, and I'll admit that's a fair business decision. And they also thought they'd appeal to the existing, massive fanbase of the LOTR LCG tabletop version. Unfortunately, the execution is poor enough that they've alienated the TT players, like myself, who balk at the dumbing down of the rules and the fact that it's way too radically different from TT to be enjoyable, and at the same time, its pricing model has failed to pull in the Hearthstone crowd as well, looking at the Steam player numbers. So they've failed on both sides.

I think they know this, their internal meetings must know that player numbers for this game on Steam are around ~52 players at any one time. And they've seen their forums and know the TT crowd is largely unhappy to not have a direct conversion of the TT game. So either some hard decisions need to happen or I don't think this game will survive very long after release and will be abandoned by the devs. Just my two cents.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254235748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1641807096}
review: 服务器极差！服务器极差！服务器极差！重要的事情说三篇，买了开始不了游戏，买了开始不了游戏，买了开始不了游戏，重要的再说三遍！

author: {'steamid': '76561198028701601', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1704492067}
review: Took a little while to get into this, restarted the first campaign several times. It felt a bit slower than the other card game I was playing at the time (Eternal - which is very fast). But I took the time to learn the mechanics better and have grown to love LoTR LCG. A card game that feels like you are on an adventure, and offers a really different experience, not a MTG or HS clone, but its own game. Great art, voice acting and progressive and immersive game play. My one quibble is that the AI on normal difficulty at least seems a bit random at times, which gives you a bit of wiggle room to learn in, but also kind of breaks the intensity when it makes silly mistakes. Also would be nice to leave game mid campaign and resume later. Despite that ruining the immersion, life sometimes necessitates a break.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129824814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1554857761}
review:
I've been enjoying me experience so far.  I have the physical game and I like what they've done so far (though there are a LOT of changes to get used to - every card is different).

Unfortunately, I've run into some bugs that are making it unplayable now :(.  When I first opened it, the game played in a window that was smaller than my screen and a little hard to read things on.  I changed my display settings and that seemed to help a LOT.  However, when I clicked the gear symbol in the game, it suddenly shrunk the window to smaller than a thumbnail and I couldn't do anything to change it.  It's still showing the full content that I saw before, but so small I can't read a thing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198298142464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1566913885}
review: 虽然和是桌游版的魔改，但就目前第一章来看还算不错，关键是接下来的更新能否体现出更多方式的冒险玩法，和尽快开通多人合作模式我觉得是非常重要的。喜欢这款游戏希望官方能尽快更新更多的内容。

author: {'steamid': '76561197966519835', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1583437059}

Perfect for dads. ;)
Can't wait for the early access to be over!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034782155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1613, 'last_played': 1700497255}
review: Even just with the first few things out for early access, plenty of replay value for someone with a completionist mindset -- trying different decks, strategies, etc.  Though FFI have changed some things significantly regarding pricing/mechanics/etc., it has never felt like a money grab and almost always directly listening to what the community wants.  Most negative reviews mention crashing, which should be expected in Early Access, or complaints about change, which have mostly been good changes IMO and also should be expected in an Early Access title.  Overall I think the mechanics and support for this game are great, I'm hoping FFI has enough support to continue releasing more and more new content for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198340444664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1540133409}
review: I bought this beta game and yet cannot play it because the window in which the game opens is so small I cannot see anything. Very frustrating that I wasted money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103549885', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3009, 'last_played': 1593835873}
review:
I knew nothing about the table top game when I purchased the Shire pack after reading a little of the game before it was released but have played many TCG both physical and digital over the years.

I am pleasently surprised how hooked I have become, the game in my opinion is great with a solid foundation moving forward. The IP is great, the artwork nice (it's a slight shame about the Hearthstone shaped unit frames) and the gameplay is deceptively deep...there is a good amount of gameplay with what is available in EA.

Like many others I am waiting to see where the devs go with the announcement that the pricing model will shortly be changng but from what I have seen in the forums and streams they are listening to the community.

As with nearly every game there are those the love it and those that dont and then there is everyone in between. If you like the TCG/LCG genre and have a a few $$ and hours I throughly recommend buying into EA at the minimum level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974631907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1661682930}
review:
Definitely still early access. As there is no quest checkpointing support be prepared to lose all quest progress amongst the numerous crashes. Quite frustrating when you have to restart the whole chain because of a mysterious hang then crash on the final boss. I suspect there is too much code dependent on dialing home, wherever home is.
The gameplay is engaging but the deck choice is not flexible. There are very few builds that actually let you win a questline. Good luck if you don't have multiple cards that give your characters the block skill.

The start of a very good game if the stability is sorted and spirit becomes a viable card set.

Edit: A lot of the stability issues seem to have been fixed, the deck viability still seems to be an issue. It mainly pays to deliberately construct decks once you know the backdrop, a lot of encounters punish you dearly if you try and stay balanced.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972799222', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1619946656}
review: Il gioco in sè non è male, tuttavia non ha nulla della compessità e profondità del gioco di carte fisico da cui è ispirato.... Purtroppo ricorda più heartstone che il suddetto, per quanto resti comunque piuttosto originale

author: {'steamid': '76561198000980797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1553199745}
review: Great game so far! Production quality is great. I'm reviewing this during EA and as such it's not perfect (e.g. could be harder, a little glitchy, needs more content), but the core gameplay is solid and I'm looking forward to more content. The music is really good too.

review:
d'abord désagréablement surpris de ne pas retrouver les règles exactes du jeu de cartes, j'ai néanmoins insisté et, ma foi, j'y ai trouvé mon compte.
Les scénarios sont immersifs avec de jolies illustrations et des textes enfin en français 
les cartes commencent à s'étoffer, et les quatre factions ont vraiment un rôle particulier comme le jeu de cartes.
Vous ne pouvez pas espérer gagner si vous comptez abattre tous les monstres qui se présentent et le choix d'utiliser des persos pour faire avancer la quête est crucial ( merci Dame Arwen)
je vais continuer à jouer et je vous encourage à insister un peu avant de vous faire un jugement, il est vraiment pas mal foutu ce jeu :)
Bons jeux à tous

author: {'steamid': '76561198068238755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5943, 'last_played': 1641128518}
review:
Tras unas cuantas horas de juego, puedo decir que si eres amante del LCG de cartas físico, este te traerá buenos recuerdos.

Ademas de la potencia que tiene para mejorar, cambiar y añadir cosas nuevas, la temática del El señor de los anillos tira muchísimo de cualquier fan.

Fantasy Flight suele hacer juegos decentes y este titulo seguro que sera el primero en la lista de una larga trayectoria de juegos de mesa que se pasan al ámbito digital.

El juego ofrece mucho, tanto en logros como en variedad, le faltan cartas si, pero se añadirán con el tiempo.

review: Auch wenn die Grafik und das Thema LOTR wirklich gelungen sind ist das Spiel an sich recht langweilig. author: {'steamid': '76561198000359152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1682519224}
review:
I've spent more money than I would ever admit on the actual LOTR LCG (because it's just such a brilliant alternative to other money-hungry TCGs) and have played through the majority of the scenarios and even some of the limited edition packs from GenCon. And I've got to say, this game is worth your time if you enjoyed the LCG, even a little! The fact that multiplayer is officially coming and *is* in the works, makes this worth investing in too (one of the best aspects of the original card game). The creative liberties taken with the stories are beautifully written and never step on the toes of Tolkien's pre-established stories (IMO) and the game mechanics for the scenarios established are well executed and interesting!

The game is different and fresh enough to warrant playing the game through, even if you've played through the other countless card game scenarios, but familiar enough that you'll feel right at home. This is an incredible digital successor to the actual card game and I question anyone saying otherwise, as perhaps they're being too nitpicky or critical to see the underlying craftsmanship of this great game.

Thanks again for another incredible board/card game presented in a freshly digital view, FFG! Keep up the great work!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132391202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2039, 'last_played': 1622832250}
review:
If you are an LotR fan, give this game a try. It is more fun than I expected, and deeper than it looks. It is much more streamlined than its physical equivalent (which I have also played), but that is not a bad thing. The new mechanics, especially Guard, may appear simple but are actually tricky and fun.

This game may not be free during early access, but it is still very cheap for what you get. Don't feel like you need to buy the biggest pack, either. I bought the Steward of Gondor pack, and was still able to unlock all the cards within a few weeks. You really only need a better pack if you want the exclusive cosmetics or want to unlock everything sooner.

Fantasy Flight Interactive has been incredible during Early Access. FFI is responsive and generous, everything you could hope for. The card pool is currently limited, but I am very excited for full access. This game is only going to improve as more content is released.

If I had to make one complaint, it's that the game doesn't try very hard to fit with LotR canon. The physical card game has a similar problem. When there are currently only 8 heroes in the game, why is one of them the made-up "Tom Took"? And what is Bilbo doing back in Mirkwood again? But these are minor complaints from a Tolkien purist. All in all the game is very fun.

To sum up, the game is quick and simple, but still deep and engaging. If you are even slightly a LotR fan, give it a try! It's worth the cheap cost, and will only become more worth it as more cards and campaigns are released. Personally, I can't wait for more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001046906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1150, 'last_played': 1603981540}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008598012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1691557286}
review:
As a big fan of the tabletop card game this game is based on, I can't wholly recommend this product just yet.  The transition to digital format makes for some major and mostly positive changes to gameplay, IMO - randomness, easier value tracking, no manual setup for scenarios.  

There are two major drawbacks:

First, the microtransactions feel pretty heavy-handed.  The card packs are not expensive, but you don't get much with each one and you will likely find yourself wanting multiple packs to create the synergies you want for your deck.  It's understandable as a monetization strategy, but providing a bit more viable content in front of the monetization wall would feel more welcoming to casual and new players.

Second, the UI is useable, but clunky, and it makes tasks like deck-building a chore.  previewing cards in small sets on screen makes the decision-making process difficult and really turns me off to that aspect of the experience.  

And viewing details of cards in play is also cumbersome, requiring the player to click on a card to view it.  During some selection modes, you can't click the cards on the table, so you must rely on your memory or best-guess to make good targeting decisions.  For example, during upkeep, you might be prompted to deal 1 damage to an enemy target (via Legolas).  The valid targets are all highlighted, but you can't click on them to see their details before making your selection.  If you target the wrong enemy which has the "Block" trait, your damage is nullified, so you end up trying to memorize the traits in play before such prompts pop up.  I would recommend using a mouse-over preview mechanic which remains active during target selection instead, so players can quickly see the cards and make their decisions without any accidental stray clicks.

Another UI fail in my mind is how traits are handled on the cards.  When a character is modified and given a new trait through a card effect, the card icon gets a little purple pip over it.  That pip stands for any and all modifiers the character might have - strength boost, guard, block, whatever.  You still need to view the card details to know what effects are on the card and as I noted earlier, that's not always easy.  Besides, some cards have native traits and others will be modified during a game.  The pip is sometimes downright misleading.  I would recommend adding a different color pip for each type of attachment (so you know it has been modified), but also using a unique icon for each major trait which is displayed on the card icons on the table.  This way a player could know at a glance which characters had Block or other traits and make decisions accordingly.  Characters with Guard are given a unique visual treatment.  This approach should be used for all traits which are important for target selection.

The game itself is pretty solid and enjoyable, but you'll quickly find yourself wanting to buy content to deepen and lengthen the experience.  Hopefully, the developers will work on streamlining the UI so players can focus more on the game itself and less on how to play it.  I could recommend this game with a little more TLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001826855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1705277086}
review:
Isengard bids 9/10.

Game's in a great state for an early access game.  Gameplay is suspenseful, polished.  Plenty of tactical choices most rounds, good strategic deck building with many different types of desks, spheres and cards offering viable alternatives.  Fantastic art, cool soundtrack, fun story-like setups for each scenario.  Makes a body feel like they got dropped in middle-earth.  Like how the scenarios build on each other to reach a high point of the story.  The Sauron deck is evil, unfair, dirty backstabbing son of a gun -- just the way we's likes it!  As a big fan of the paper LotR LCG, at first I was concerned about the electronic adoption, that it would be too dumbed down, etc.  Now I like it for it's speed and flow, while still allowing for plenty of thoughtful choices and desk building.  Game's not perfect, but in the current excellent state, responsive devs (appreciated how the entire first campaign was unlocked after player feedback), I think this game has a bright future ahead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263564035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1596824849}

Perfect game for Lord of the Rings fans and and people who like card games such as Hearthstone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148406780', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1539426311}
review:
I like it!
In the campaign you have to build a deck to defeat Sauron by completing objectives. 

It has similarities to games like Heartstone but there's more depth to it thanks to a third card attribute called "Willpower" in addition to health and attack. There's various purposes it can be used for like add it to a pool, which if you have enough provides certain powers. There's also more actions for each card than just attack, like using powers or guarding.

You also have 3 heroes to chose for a deck with various abilities, these also affect the cards you can pick per deck. These heroes are put on the board at the start of the game and are very powerful. 

It is mostly a single player game with co-op in the future, so if you're looking for a pvp game, this might not be the card game you want.

The audio is excelent, the writing is good and the campaign story is voice acted. I like how each card you play is an important decission and you have to really think to solve a given situation. The graphics are nice but might need some work on the anti aliasing of the cards and text. There's also not a lot of cards at the moment so there's very limited versatility when building a deck. This is also the biggest reason you might want to hold of buying if you're interested in experimenting with a lot of decks.

Overall I'd say this game has a lot of potential and if a lot more content gets added by the end of Early Access it'll make a great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051821309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2562, 'last_played': 1646085740}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002462499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1653870978}
review:
1. What do I think: I really like this game and think it stands out from the crowd. Not only do I like the PvE concept but the theme, story elements, triggered events, the unique heroes and their abilities.

2. Experience: I've played a little bit of Magic the Gathering, Hearthstone, and Faeria but relatively new to card games

3. Tougness: This game is definitely not easy, you really have to think what heroes and cards you want in your deck and when you want to play the cards. I am getting used to the gameplay in which a character action and card action are treated the same and the move-for-move turn style.

4. Replayability: Even though there is only on campaign right now I find each time it is a bit different depending on the events and cards Sauron plays. For instance just was decimated when Sauron summoned ten creatures on the board! 

4. Digital vs Physical: I never played the physical LOTR card games but I find that many physical card games can become bogged down and tedious. I really love the idea of digitizing card games because it flows a lot nicer and the developer can incorporate some unique elements that make the game more fun and engaging.

5. Co-Op: I can't wait to try the co-op mode which can make this game different than other popular card games. Edit: Just tried the co-op mode and I really like it. It adds another dimension of team tactics and deck building ideas. Even my brother liked it!

6. Other Reviews: It seems like other reviewers are unhappy because they expected a 1:1 physical to digital card game. Why would someone want to buy a digital version of something you can buy physically? Also how can you evolve and improve a game if all you did was copy the previous? Also some reviewers don't understand that early access means you are practically a test-player to offer feedback to help the developers improve. I believe that some of the previous issues have been addressed for those still interested in this game.

7. Overall: Currently this is one of my go-to games if I want something strategic and relaxing. Not only do I love LOTR but this living card game is already in my opinion going to be better than Hearthstone, Magic, or anything else. I can't really put my finger on why, but I found those other games somewhat flawed or monotonous in mechanics, dependant on chance, pay-to-win, and simply a money-pit. I'm not saying this game is perfect but I really like the direction the developers are taking. Cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076730541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1606999133}
review:
I have been playing the Lord of the Ring LCG as the original cardgame for a long time. I agree that it is confusing that the title of the PC Game is the same as the one of the cardgame while the content is different. However, the game in itself shows great promise and for me is fun to play.

The main changes are that the opponent is an AI instead of a predefined deck. However, the cards available to the AI are restricted to the scenario. Furthermore, the ressources available to the AI show which cards could possibly be played this turn which adds another tactical dimension for the player. Furthermore, actions are now played in succession - every turn is started by the player and followed up by the AI until both pass. There are no more phases. As a result the fate and threat system work differently, granting bonuses and disadvantages when threshholds are reached. Threat is increased by 1 each turn automatically and effect by many card effect of the AI. Reaching 50 threat still loses the game as does losing all heroes.

The first campaign is free with the lowest buy on Steam. I enjoyed it a great time, even though it is quite rough and playtests the game more than it adds exotic mechanisms. The atmosphere, UI, Audio and Storytelling are superb! I played through the campaign multiple times and enjoyed it a lot.

The deckbuilding is not very well designed. To few filters (filtering for fragments of text on the card, traits,...) and information (e.g.: a cost curve for the deck) are available. However, that could be easily fixed by the designers. 

The price system is fair, motivating (you get currency based on your performance) and transparent. I would be very happy to buy the DLCs (New campaings) if they contain one new hero and some cards like in the card game. As it is usual for an LCG you dont open boosters but always know what you get. 


[b]TL;DR:[/b]
If the game tries more exotic and interesting mechanisms and tweaks with the AI and future campaigns it will replace the card game for me in points of fun. I recommend the game in it's current state, but it is not yet fully fleshed out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105917829', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1537710540}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021574186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1623378068}
review:
I love board games. There are board games that I have yet to even take the plastic off of. I love video games. My digital game backlog outgrows my ability to play games. So when two of my favorite worlds collided I kind of geeked out a tad bit. I’ve been a fan of Lord of the Rings since before I can remember. I have memories of sitting on the couch watching the Lord of the Rings animated movies as my dad tried to explain to me all the characters and what was going on. When I was older my best friend and I sat and watched all of the Extended Editions back to back while playing Lord of the Rings Online together. When Fellowship first came to theaters I choose to walk around all summer barefoot to make my feet tough and leathery like a hobbit. I am a nerd, and I love the world of Middle Earth. So yes, maybe I am not an authority on card games, I suck at MTG and fell out of competitive Hearthstone quickly, but I do live and breathe Lord of the Rings.

So it’s obvious I would be all over The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game for PC.  I picked the board game version up at my local gaming store years prior and devoured its contents. My friends and I played countless times and enjoyed the cooperative nature of the game. Being a “living card game” you don't need to buy boosters or hunt down the flavor of the month style cards. Everything you need is in the box. This doesn’t stop the developers from releasing expansions sets to add new cards and adventures, although everything you need is again in those boxes as well. The hook of these living card games was a huge draw to me, a scorned Magic player, and not needing to sink hundreds of dollars into a game just to stay relevant was awesome. If any of that can be replicated or emulated in the digital space, I truly believe this game will explode on the scene.
At its core, Lord of the Rings: LCG is a cooperative experience, and I was hoping it stayed that way in the digital adaptation. Although the game sports only a single player option at the moment, the digital take on this tabletop game stays true to its roots. If players are familiar with the physical version they will feel right at home in the new digital Middle Earth. Although not a copy and paste job, Fantasy Flight Interactive does a great job adapting the digital game to be very similar to the physical one. You’ll be completing quests, fighting monsters, and recruiting allies to fight by your side. Players unfamiliar with the game will still understand how to play after the first few hands if they are knowledgeable with games like Hearthstone and Eternal. Although Lord of the Rings has many unique and notable differences from a typical card game.

The main difference is defeating the enemy is not always the main goal. Completing quests by exhausting your heroes and spending their resource power can be more important than taking down that cave troll. This brings a lot of risk assessment and management to each action you take. Do you push your luck for a board clear and then whittle away at the quest or rush through the quest while taking damage from the monsters? Each tactic has its boons and setbacks, it’s up to you as the player to decide which is best and adapts depending on the cards you have. Each match has a few phases, maybe you're adventuring through the forest of Mirkwood and get attacked by spiders, the first round you’ll defeat the spiders then you’ll “adventure”  to the next phase where your companion has been captured and you must tear open the cocoon it was wrapped in. A few more phases and you’re fighting a giant spider who is the matches final boss. Each round has a unique objective, and these rounds are tied together with a compelling, although I believe noncanonical, story to form an action-packed match.

I am thoroughly enjoying my time spent in game. Each turn starts to feel more familiar and exciting, the story is interesting and compelling, and I haven’t once felt nickel and dimed while playing. I am excited to see the multiplayer they add and to see a roadmap of content for expansion releases. I really believe this game has the staying power for people who are tired of the same old types of collectible card games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107688120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1574415228}

author: {'steamid': '76561197965291790', 'num_games_owned': 900, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2658, 'last_played': 1683318604}
review:
If you're a fan of FFG's Lord of the Rings: LCG, then know this: this game is not a carbon copy of that card game experience. It is a streamlined version of that game, with a number of interesting changes.

Interesting how? Instead of having delegated phases to dealing with drawing cards, questing, having new problems show up, blocking, and attacking the minions of Sauron, this digital adaptation plays like a game of high-fantasy tennis: you and Sauron take actions back and forth playing allies, events or attachments, commanding them to block or defeat enemies, or help with questing hazards and objectives. It creates an interesting dynamic that makes the game quite challenging, especially on Hard mode.

This game is still in Early Access, but the developers have been listening patiently to the players about ways to make it better. Coop mode is on the way, as is more cards to finagle with. The game is quite barebones right now, but what is here is interesting to start with! It does feature some elements of pay2play though, so that might not be everyone's cup of tea. I did pay for the second tier to try out the Early Access and haven't been compelled to buy anything else though!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030493701', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1709439583}
review:
Excellent conversion of a great game into a new medium.

The tabletop version is one of those games that I always feel I should get out and play, but usually end up leaving on the shelf in favor of something else. It's never quite as much fun as it shold be, because unless you really enjoy physical deckbuilding, it can be a pain to manage. I always see the potential for fun, but I rarely actually have, you know, fun.

This translation simplifies some things and adds some others, but keeps the essentials that make the game fun and strategic. In playing this - even for just 4 hours - I've found myself replaying the same scenario over and over again to see different ways of handling things and having a blast, whether I win or lose. I'm understanding the game better than I understood the tabletop version (and I spent many more hours on it).

Somehow, they managed carve out the things that were getting in the way of the fun for me, and amplify what makes the game brilliant. I own a number of electronic versions of tabletop games, and most go for a straight conversion. This is an approach that more should consider. 

Yes, it's expensive, but you should try the tabletop game some time. I do feel that the valor points are a little hard to come by, but this might get adjusted over time. Even if it doesn't, I've spent $15 so far, which is less than half of what I spent on just the base set that has been sitting on my shelf for most of the last 4 years.

The thing I think I don't like is the Palintir. One of the original selling points of the LCG model is that you always know what you're going to get for your money. No loot boxes, no random, ever. The game is so good that it doesn't need the gambling element. I wish they had stayed truer to the tabletop model. Marketing won the day on this one.

Overall, this is one of the best, if not the best, translations of a great tabletop game that I've seen. If you want the exact version of the card game, go to Tabletop Simulator. If you want something that changes the game and in doing so enhances what makes the game fun, give this a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971612682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1815, 'last_played': 1611329184}
review:
Very decent game, if you like it or not, will very much depend on your expectations of this game. It is a different game than the physical LCG by Fantasy Flight Games, so do not expect a simple copy of that game. This might be good or bad, depending on your expectations. Surely this was a good decision in my opinion, so both games can co-exist beside each other, not making the other one obsolete.

The Business Model seems to be very fair in my perspective, if you use the Palantir system in the right way, you can save a lot of time unlocking the Legendary, Rare and Uncommon cards.

There's a lot of fun to be had here, but do expect to grind a lot in this game, as you will play every Mission over and over until you get the perfect Score, in order to unlock more VP and Palantir Views.

Also do not expect a HeartStone like game, it has no Multiplayer at all at the Moment, there will be a Co-Op Mode in the future, but there will never be Player vs. Player battles.

If you buy a "Booster Pack" in this game you know exactly what you will get, since this game is not a Collectible Card Game (CCG), but a Living Card Game (LCG), so there will be previews of the content in any pack you can buy, which contains a new hero and 4 additional Cards +1 Palantir View. With every hero you will be able to unlock more Palantir Views in the campaign and one single + 50VP Reward per Mission.

The Missions themselves will be purchasable as well. Right now in Early Access, they give you the whole first campaign completely unlocked, which includes 5 Quests.

The Missions and the Hero Packs can be purchased with Real Money, or unlocked with In-Game Currency.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968851498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1684415673}
review:
Disclaimer: I have never played the Lord of the Rings Living card game and this review is for the Early Access version.

The good: The game is very thematic. The story is entertaining. The game play choices are interesting. 

The bad: Microtransactions out the wazoo. Want a new hero? $$$, how about a new card? $$$, a new adventure? $$$ or just a random loot box? $$$. Stop already.  I would much prefer, here is a new adventure along with some new heroes and cards to play with. Costs X dollars. And do away with all the valor points, loot boxes. 

The ugly: The tutorial was not bad, but a lot is missing. The fact that fate events are free, that Sauron gets threat each turn, what all the keywords mean. A glossary is available, but don't make me pull it up. Let me hover over the keyword on a card and bring up a tooltip.  The tutorial was obviously written for folks that have played the card game. 

Overall I feel like I got my $7 worth, but I am worried going forward the game will drown in micro-transactions pushing me away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006780231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1603054443}
review:
Well this is  first review for me 
I have never played the real card game - I was an early player of deciphers TCG which was wonderful but then closed down and all of my online cards were obliterated 
I am very hopeful this game succeeds - there are so many grumblers in this world and complainers I am surprised there are any mainly positive let alone overwhelmingly posoitive ones for games  on steam !
The main complaints seem to be from People seem to want free stuff and want the same things as the real card game - 
all i want is a card game of LOTR and in that this is great with lovely ambience and production values and good ,and for me, difficult game play 
I'm not bothered about the pay for play stuff i don't see this as a TCG where you are constantly needing packs 
obviously as its early access there is a need for more cards and I can't wait for more quests that delve beyond the hobbit and mirkwood and lead into the war of the ring 
I am giving this a very posiotve reveiw and hope that the negative ones don't put off LOTR fnas and card fans as I want this to succeed where decipher fell 
i'd like the decipher game back again too as people are now more into the card games than they were - i know there are places you can still play it but it needs the music production values nd sound effects of eomsthig like this to come alive stuff which the negative boys don't give any credit for

author: {'steamid': '76561198020457456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 936, 'last_played': 1574617792}
review:
Yo he jugado al Arkham Horror LCG de mesa y me ha parecido un buen juego. Estaba pensando en comprarme el del señor de los anillos pero justo ha salido esta versión para PC.

Lo he jugado y me he pasado la primera campaña.

El juego está bien, es entretenido y hay algo de reto con lo que puedes estar picado bastante rato.

La historia está bien aunque se agradece que lo estén traduciendo al castellano porque hay muchos matices que seguramente estoy pasando por alto.

Si te gustan los juegos de cartas de FFG esté te gustará, tiene los mismos elementos de planficación, combos y estrategia.

Yo te lo recomiendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019239119', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1557759961}
review:
Una muy buena aproximación al juego de cartas. Obviamente se ha tomado una gran cantidad de licencias respecto del juego original para su adaptación al medio digital, pero creo que merece la pena el relativo sacrificio para tener una experiencia de juego ideal.

Entre la multitud de juegos de cartas que han aparecido siguiendo la estela de Heartstone es un solplo de aire fresco ya que ofrece una experiencia para un solo jugador que para los aficionados a la temática de la Tierra Media es apasionante. Un tipo de juego narrativo en forma de misiones que en el futuro contará, así como en el juego de mesa, la opción de jugar de modo cooperativo.

La dificultad está muy medida, con tres grados de dificultad diferente para que al principio, cuando no tienes demasiadas cartas resulte desafiante y según conformas tu mazo y se vuelve más sencillo, poder aumentar la dificultad para seguir siendo un desafío. Tampoco es difícil poder conseguir puntos de cara a adquirir de forma gratuita más cartas y en el futuro más contenido en forma de misiones y campañas, por supuesto que hace falta, como dicen algunos, meterle muchas horas para conseguirlo sin pasar por caja, pero todos los juegos de este tipo son así y este no me parece que sea de los peores ni mucho menos.

Mención especial para las ilustraciones de las cartas, pantallas de transición, etc, que compartten con el juego de mesa original y son una verdadera maravilla para el aficionado a Tolkien.

Espero con ganas las próximas actualizaciones de contenido y la implementación del modo cooperativo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042517203', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1543242654}
review: I have gradually warmed up to this game. Paywall is noticeably less than most other F2P card games as the 'loot box' system guarantees a non-duplicate card, which is refreshing. Currency is also not too difficult to gain (although the daily quests, for the amount of effort needed, should reward you with more Valor points imo). Gameplay is unique and probably one of the better PvE card games I've played. Keep up the good work!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005194656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1555179750}
review: I have been playing the tabletop version of this game for years and much has been retained in the digital format; story driven, intelligent deck customization, challenging choices, beautiful artwork, thematic, etc. The digital version is in its infancy, however, I am pleased with the platform and where they are headed with it. I have read a lot of people complaining about pricing, it takes time for the in game economy to match customer and developer needs but I think FFI will create an environment that we can all agree to. Developers have been listening to customer feedback in the forums. Keep in mind that the LOTR LCG tabletop is not cheap either. Haha. Thank you FFI for taking this fantastic card game and bringing it to our PC's! Keep up the great work and look forward to more content to come!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008702027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1540908373}
review:
I find this game to be interesting and enjoyable, and I can't wait to see what it will develop into. While it had it's startup problems in regards to economy etc., the devs were really supportive and listening to community. They threw themselves around and changed the economy of the game already in the first few weeks. This gives me high hopes of the future of the game itself. 

I've never played the lotr lcg, but I've played lots of Lord of the Rings trading card game back in the days. The lore is nice and interesting, and the mechanics are unlike other tcg's I've been playing recently. So far it's been an enjoyable experience, and I think the game deserves more than a mixed review, even in its current state. Looking forward to play more after new content arrives :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198022817498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1566709190}
review:
音楽、グラフィックともにロード・オブ・ザ・リングの世界にどっぷり浸れる。
シナリオも分岐点等もあってかなり面白い。またサウロン側も非常に強く歯ごたえがある。簡単には勝たせてくれない。
デッキの組み方にもよるが、バランスはかなり良い方だと思う。
日本語はないが、キャプチャー翻訳を使えば、ほとんど問題ない。
まだ早期アクセスの段階で色々制約があっても面白いので、今後のコンテンツの増加によっては、かなり楽しみである。期待したい。
