author: {'steamid': '76561197972670066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1537942684}
review: It's free and it's fun! There isn't much else to be said other than you should give it a try. I've seen criticism of the monetisation, but personally have absolutely no problem with it. I would highly recommend getting all available missions as this makes things much more efficient. It's impossible to sink ridiculous money into this game as you only ever obtain cards that you can use (up to a maximum of 2). Meaning you complete your collection much more reasonably than other F2P games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156855460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 4031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1638581743}
review: Of course the game is early access and there isnt heaps of content yet but I like what I see so far and the one complaint I had about it was having to unlock the campaign quests to play them and they fixed it and made it free for everyone within 2 days of launch. The devs for this are taking feedback into consideration very well and I have high hopes for where this game is going to go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002923939', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1677747307}
review: Играл достаточно долго в оригинальную настольную, эта, конечно сильно отличается и явно не в лучшую сторону. Тем не менее пока аналогов с подобным стилем карточной игры я не видел. В принципе играть интересно, но скорее всего проходить одни и те же сценарии много раз, быстро наскучит. Купил версию за 200 руб, в течение следующих 2 часов докупил за внутриигровую валюту 2 сценария. Деньги набираются долго, по 200-300 за сценарий. Стоимость сценария 3750.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039895342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2639, 'last_played': 1708215371}
review: Attention: Dont let the mixed reviews fool you. This game is fun! Its new and refreshing, has very unique designs in style and gameplay. Lots of the thumb's down are due to people complaining about playing a early access game. They dont want to help finance the game, test the game, play the game early. They expect it all for free and complain all cards were not given to them or the quests. So far its been a great experiance worth the $ for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978411456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1608643905}
review:
I have never before offered a review of a game.  So as this is my first review you will understand the passion with which I wrote this.

No...simply...no!

If I had wanted to play Hearthstone I would play Hearthstone.  This game is no where near the brillliance that is the LOTR LCG! 

The micro-transactions alone is enough to kill this game for me because of how aggressive of a structure it is.  

And then we get to the gameplay....how in the name of <*censored by myself*> can you call this a LOTR:LCG game?!  This is *NOWHERE*  close to the gameplay found in the real version released by FFG.  This is Hearthstone with a veneer of of LOTR:LCG.  You may as well just call this Hearthstone:  LOTR edition and be done with it!

In brief....this is not a game I would reccomend for people who enjog the LOTR:LCG, nor would I recomend this to the hearthstone crowd due to the overly aggressive micro-transaction scheme.  I *STRONGLY* suggest the powers that be read these reviews and take action before this game becomes a critical failure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042082424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1655626483}
review:
感觉不如原作规则好。有种硬是用炉石体系的交互来套原作并魔改的感觉。感觉上少了不少核心体验，一些地方还有点生硬（比如经常频繁的因为7个生物格子满了替换原单位。因为敌方生物AI攻击选择目标随机性导致策略控制很迷。）
与其这样还不如跳出原作的影子，彻底做一个不一样的。

author: {'steamid': '76561198062514435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1703135008}
review:
Edit: I will leave my original review, but do note that FFG has unlocked the campaign for all. I'd say thank you, but that should've been a given from the start. However, I do thank FFG for their extremely quick response. That does mean they are listening.

Buyer beware, not all is as it seems.

I spent $50 on the most expensive pass, and after buying all of the characters and most (note, not all) of the cards available to buy, I soon find out that the locks on the campaign are not locked because I need to beat the previous section, but I need to buy them. Each. Each level out of a campaign must be bought. I sunk 50 dollars right off the bat, and I am already not allowed to play the content without paying more. 

Not to mention, this is LotR: Destiny, not LotR LCG. I have almost all of the tabletop cards, and this feels very different. 

This is not a bad game by any means. There are minor UI issues I have, such as not seeing a card from hovering over it (you must click it), and rotten card sorting when deckbuilding.

And the fact that it is very different than the tabletop version isn't bad, but they should definitely play that up.

But in its current form, this is a money grabbing scheme that Battlefront II is jealous of. It is ridiculous that in good faith, because I love the tabletop LCG (and have sunk hundreds of dollars into that), that I find later that I cannot play all of the content. It's pathetic, and it stinks of desperation, especially on their maiden voyage into digital card games.

Shame on you, FFG. I want to like this game, but I cannot support the business model. But I guess you don't care right? You already got my money.

Buyer beware.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992098922', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1701559819}
review: Simple, yet difficult missions.  Don't feel it's too random (pretty easy to rough guess what's going to happen in order to make a decision on how to deal with it).  Nice story, voice, and art.  Company seems to be very transparent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001570424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1682867667}
review:
This is not the same game as the Physical Lord of the Rings LCG...

And that's ok! It is still a highly thematic, story-driven, tactical card game, that has been a real joy to play so far! 

The pricing is very fair ($2.00 may seem steep for a quest, but consider all the voiceover work, art, programming, testing, etc). I can't wait to see what lies ahead for this one!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982670012', 'num_games_owned': 2385, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1573867419}
review:
I wish there were a "neutral" recommendation as I can't fully endorse the game as is, but it's gotten me to come back for repeat sessions so I'll err to the side of positive as I'm cautiously optimistic about adjustments to be made as Early Access continues.

I've never been huge into the physical LOTR LCG (more of a Netrunner man myself) but I've gotten to play many a game thanks to friends.  It's notorious for being brutally difficult, often complicated, and -- unusual for games of this nature -- entirely cooperative.

The digital version isn't really any of these three things.  As far as difficulty is concerned I've not managed to lose a game, not even getting a hero killed, even playing on Hard mode.  So far I only have access to the first three quests so this may change in later quests, but as of this writing there are only five quests available total so I'm not holding my breath.  A lot of this can be chocked up to the Sauron AI which takes the place of the random deck of enemy cards from the physical game.  You'd figure the AI would be absolutely ruthless at the hard difficulty mode, but this is not the case.  Sauron will pass up on dogpiling a vulnerable hero down to their last few HP to spread the damage among other healthier and less important targets.  I've often been left wondering what the algorithm could be thinking when making its choices, and while it could be chalked up to bad AI I get more of the sense that Sauron is straight up going easy on us.  If there's one gripe I have with the gameplay itself it's this -- in the physical version I've lost as many games as I've won.  The only real risk of defeat is coming into a quest with a bad deck of cards, and even players with no prior experience with the LCG will probably find themselves confident on any repeat adventure once they learn the ins and outs.

And that's bad because the game expects you to repeat those quests!  I started this early access the same way I would any online card game -- I put some money upfront (the middle tier "Steward of Gondor" pack) in the hopes that I can earn everything else through play.  Things started out great -- I had enough in game currency to grab a couple more heroes and was getting generous rewards.  Every quest will reward you the first time you clear it at a particular level of efficiency, which includes more currency and "Palantir Views" (which are kind of like loot boxes, though ultimately fairer since it will never give you useless duplicates to cards you already have, while any individual card can be bought non-randomly in the card shop).  Beating a quest for the first time in a day can reward you up to 325 currency points, which isn't a whole lot but along with the other bonuses should have you earning new cards and quests at a good clip.

The problem starts when these resources dry up. Once you've beaten every quest with every hero, the stream of currency slows down to a trickle.  The same quests -- of which there are only 5, and 4 have to be unlocked with the very currency you're trying to earn -- will only reward up to 75 currency per play after their first daily run, and that's only if you're playing on hard mode.  Keeping in mind unlocking new quests and characters -- probably what you want to be spending your currency on until you've unlocked all that are available -- cost over 3000 currency apiece.  So once you hit this wall you have the options of endlessly grinding the same few quests over and over, patiently getting your max bonuses day by day till you can unlock something cool, or opening up the real life wallet.

(On a sidenote there are daily quests available to, which seem to come in sets of 3 and reward 90 to 125 currency apiece, but these are a mixed bag.  Mine for today include playing 20 Lore cards (easy), playing 20 Unique Allies (Time consuming, as it's not uncommon to play a game where you summon 0 unique allies if you even have some in your deck to begin with) and lastly to finish 3 hard quests.  The rub being that the last one seems like it would be no problem, but it's not working, showing me at 0/3 progress after I've completed 2 hard quests.)

Lastly, co-op -- a vital part of the original game -- isn't currently active, so if you're grinding out those quests you'll be doing it all alone.  The co-op mode button is there with a "coming soon" hover on it, and we've seen it in action during developer Let's Plays, so hopefully this feature is rolled out sooner rather than later.  Playing with a friend can go a long way to spicing up a quest you've been through a half dozen times by yourself.

So scrolling up I see a lot of criticism for a game I already put $14 into, so why still a positive recommendation?  Because there's a lot here to like!  Though I think the game system will shine brightest in co-op, I found the digital version of the game to be a lighter, snappier version of the physical version that even in its current state is a good time waster.  Production values are better than I was expecting with fully voiced characters and narrative interludes.  The deck building interface is fun and easy.  The launch card library isn't terribly complex but has some fun options and seems appropriate for an under the microscope early access release.  And while currency drops get too stingy too quickly, there are a lot of aspects of card shopping I quite like, like being able to outright purchase specific cards instead of hoping to randomly get them while random "gets" are guaranteed not to be unusable dupes.

Basically it's a solid foundation and more or less what I feel an Early Access title should be.  Assuming developers are listening these issues will see adjustment moving forward while the problem of being light on content should fix itself as the game is built on.  I plan on sticking around and watching how things proceed... though of course if they muck it up I'll be coming back to change that thumbs up the other way around.

In short if you like online card games but want something less competitive based and more cooperative, AND you like being along for the Early Access ride, this is a solid recommendation, with the warning that the flow of free currency gets dammed up pretty quick.  If either the genre, the slow currency, or being an Early Access guinea pig are not your thing you may want to wait on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006784691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 255, 'playtime_forever': 6897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2156, 'last_played': 1615219979}
review:
Игра очень сильно изменилась в сравнении с настольной версией. Пожалуй в сторону упрощения механики. И хотя тематика, оформление и идеи остались, игры слишком разные. Это как если сравнить Lord of the Rings LCG с Arkham Horror LCG по механикам. Вроде где-то похоже, но все иначе.
 
Кратко:

- полностью изменены механики угрозы, света и путешествия (пока оцениваю нейтрально)
- ресурс в игре одного вида, а карты в колоду допускаются по числу героев одной сферы (пока оцениваю нейтрально)
- за Саурона теперь играет "настоящий" ИИ, а не некий детерминированный (что имхо минус игре, так как значительно ослаблен элемент паззла), отсюда и отсутствие угрозы у врагов, и другая механика защиты от атак
 
Зато в игре появилась вроде атмосферная озвучка.

ЗЫ. Пожалуй яйцеобразные аватары игре не идут.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965595599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1604144966}
review:
The two points that made me go 'ewww' initially where the abundance of microtransactions and that valor point rewards for completing a quest are capped at once per day and quest.

After playing for a few hours now, I feel a lot better about the game. Although you can't farm a specific quest multiple times (which is actually okay if I'm honest with myself - otherwise I'd just play quest 1 all day long and slowly lose my mind), you still get extra valor when finishing a quest with a score of 200+ and 250+.

With my initial Ishtari valor points and some rewards, I have now unlocked 4 quests. I can easily gain 1.000 valor a day now. Even more when you factor in the daily rewards or rewards for scoring high. Now the game rewards feels a lot fairer compared to the beginning when I had only 1 quest to choose from.

Ah, and btw: That game is quite fun to play ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561197962313629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1619208104}
review:
This game is great. The production value is up there; the gameplay is fun, engaging, and far from a Hearthstone clone (while still paying homage to the tabletop original); and visually it is a treat.

The major complaints are that you don't get enough for free. I'm not real sure what people expect. I take no issue with the current game economy, even though it will probably change towards full release. I think it's perfectly reasonable.

There are a few UI/UX issues that I'm sure will get hammered out during early access. Other than that, if you like single player games, card games, and/or Middle-earth this is worth the $8 (or whatever) to get you into early access. Give it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074611608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1535569247}
review:
Warning for the fans of the physical card game: this game uses the same artwork, but has absolutely no other connection! It is another hearthstone clone, even using willpower to overcome obstacles has been turned into a form of attack. 
And as a further insult there is a line in the intro that says "hands reach with greedy fingers...". When i see the number of microtransactions and lootboxes in the game, then i think they describe themselves, not sauron...

author: {'steamid': '76561197997714504', 'num_games_owned': 2308, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1650253950}
review: Not quite as good as the physical game but the LCG was used as a blueprint so it is similar in many ways. Should scratch the itch if you're looking for that type of experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010903811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1407, 'last_played': 1616531435}
review:
I have owned the game since the game was released and I have been putting off playing it for awhile now. No particular reason other than putting time into other hobbies. I am now regretting that because this game is a lot of fun. I can't say I have ever gotten my ass kicked by an AI in a computer game so many times and actually felt so determined to win. ( usually I'd lose interest) It's got a bit of a learning curve to it, but it's rewarding once you get the mechanics. My only suggestions to the devs is to make it more obvious when enemy units have abilitys, for example, add some kind of icon to the image so I dont have to click on every wolf to see what they have on them. I believe this will speed up game time a little bit as well.

Very fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198351310732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 17671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1707880743}
review:
I have played the physical version and like it,I have about 40% of whats out currently.  I have played through the first mission of this game.

The quality of what they have done so far is great I mean great.  The music and voice acting are top noch really bring you into the world well done FFI.  

The game is different from the table top version but not really in feel.  You still have threat and it acts the same.  You still have shawdows that give nasty surprise in combat. You still have four or so phases to each quest.  You still need to balance out questing, defending and attacking just in a differnt way then the table top.  Its one turn at a time and I realy like it.  Lots of people are saying its not complex.  I dont feel that is true. Complexity in the table top comes from all the card interactions.  In the physical game you do get 5 or more card ineractions typicaly at once.  This game has the same amount of card interactions going about 5 or so once the game gets going.

The one thing that is less complex is the resourses in this game as you dont need resource matches.  The matching happens in deck building as you need a hero in sphere to use the cards in that shere also some cards need two heros of that type to play.  They have added resources to the computer deck which brings back any complexity lost with the resource matching from the table top game I feel.  

If you bought the bigger founder packs 15$ and up they give you enough in game currency to buy everythig they have made so far.  So give them 15$ and you can play all the EA content.  I payed the 8$ and really like it as I get to try this out and buy things with the in game money I want, not wast it on stuff I wont use.  I like to play lore so will focus on bulding lore decks and wont spend a lot of money say on leadership for example. 

The game is not free to play it is an Lcg. which means you pay to expand at your own pace you buy what you want or spend some time to get some free bees if you want.  Its a new way to pay for a Cpu game so its confusing. 

Once co-op comes out the game will really hit its stride with card inter actions and complexity to get the full experiance if you are on the fence I would wait till the co-op comes out and then get a friend spend 8 dollars and then play the game I really think when people get to experence this part of the game the rating for this game will shoot up.  Thats the part of the game that is so great in the physical version and why its so complex this one will too once you can play coop.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968343392', 'num_games_owned': 2286, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1549914351}
review:
Incredibly compelling, just don't expect the exact same game as the physical LCG. If you are not familiar with either the physical or digital LCG, you may want to watch some streams and do some reading up on this before you jump in (or wait until this goes free to play in release).

This is a cooperative only game (like the physical) and it is very fun to play even at this early stage. The graphics, music, sounds, and narration are all top notch. The gameplay is a mix of hearthstone and the physical LCG. If you aren't familiar with both of those, the game play is very fast, with each side taking a quick action before the other side responds. It isn't all about combat, but you'll often have to fight in at least some stages of each quest. Your tactical options are numerous and you have to make difficult decisions often about which aspect of the game to concentrate on next (such as slowing down Sauron's threat, raising your own fate, taking out combat threats, clearing locations, advancing the quest, and building up your heroes with more allies and equipment).

There are certainly some bugs, but nothing game breaking that I have found. There are also some microtransactions, but like all LCG games, there is no randomness involved (there is some randomness with the palantir, but those are bonus rewards, and you cannot buy them directly with real money). You know exactly what you are getting in each hero pack and each quest that you decide to purchase. Beyond that, you can buy individual cards directly using in-game valor points.

No one is really sure how this experiment is going to turn out, but in my opinion this is a great start. I eagerly await the coming bug fixes and new content!

author: {'steamid': '76561198407978658', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1699379019}
review: I am a fan of the card game. And I think this game is just as fun as the card game without all the set up and overhead that comes with the physical game. That's what killed the actual game for me was all the crap to remember.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111932784', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1615512686}
review:
Everyone keeps saying it's BS you gotta buy EA then gotta buy money to get anything it's like they don't even acknowledge they get in game money to buy anything in game and buying the 15$ pack lets you get every quest in the campaign. You also need 3700 to buy a hero pack so you can either buy quest or every hero pack and have valor left over to grind for the other stuff. 

While I have Issues everyone calling this an extremist cash grab game is ignoring a lot of things the devolopers give you to [i]buy stuff for free[/i]. Please ignore any review calling BS on this game for money reasons. 

The game is a bit difficult but I think there is just a learning curve not many people have due to being used to HS.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985925929', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1686177121}
review:
I wish the promotional video had the part where you finish a quest for the second time and the end screen pops up letting you know you do not get full quest rewards, but to try again tomorrow. 

It is incredibly insulting to time-lock quest rewards when we've ALREADY PAID TO PLAY THE GAME. At least you are being 100% transparent about your greed, but seriously get rid of the free to play shady tactics for the people who are ultimately paying to play-test your game.

Not to mention a really neat game-breaking glitch I came across. After playing an ally it gets stuck in animation and doesn't actually make it to the board. You are then unable to play any other card from your hand. For the rest of the game. However, you can still perform actions for allies/heroes on the board. So this glitch happens on the final act of the first quest (on hard difficulty) and I STILL beat it without having played another card the rest of the quest. Get super amped because it was pretty awesome to pull off and the screen says "You do not get full quest rewards, try again tomorrow!"

Well guess what, I have a whole case of Ligma here for you if you want some FFI. Out of principle I will not be playing this game or spending another cent on it. I wish I hadn't left the game running on my lunch break to accrue these hours because now I can't get a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962492522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1538534594}
review:
It appears that most peoples problems stem from the "F2P" model; to that end, honestly, the model seems a tad harsh and should offer more content than what you get. That being said, this being Early Access, I'm sure the Developers are listening and the model can be revised before the full release.

Now that I can move past that elephant in the room, the game is quite a lot of fun. For those looking for a strategic deckbuilding/deck construction card game that doesn't have the "pay to win" model of competitive CCG's then this is at least worth a look. There are some balance issues and some things that are rough around the edges (hey, this is Early Access), but this is a strong foundation to work off of; the mechanics are fun, tactical, and hard as hell. Is it as deep as the tabletop game? No, but that's a game that has had 7 years of development (and as much as I love it, a pretty obtuse rule structure/faq); I'm sure this game will get there in time, and has a very clean system to work with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028889433', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1636263315}

author: {'steamid': '76561198079724968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1546086433}
review:
after some initial struggles the game had it looks ok now,
still not polished, but thats fine
still not on the same gameplay level then slay the spire (and it probably never will be)

expansion will cost money in the future and its no longer f2p or "grind to play",
which is probably fine aswell


im not sure yet if i will get future expansions or continue playing.

but i change my vote from nay to yay.
not because the game is super great - its like 70/100

but the devs put effort in it to improve it (at least right now) - so there is hope for the future.

so get it if you are LotR fan and like PvE card games
if you are not - get Slay the spire first ;)


interesting things for the future to come will be the multiplayer mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975118240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1536963123}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026692751', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 980, 'last_played': 1641005848}
review:
After almost 6 hours of game play here is an honest review.

This game is exactly what I expected it to be. I have been following this game since they started streaming and I have watched every one. If you purchased a founders pack without watching the streams and continue to complain, then shame on you for not understanding what you were getting yourself in to. 

This game follows the Living Card Game model. Yes it is riddled with microtransactions for hero packs and quests. No you dont have to spend any money beyond the basic founders pack, but you will never unlock all of the content with the games current economy and time locked rewards. If you purchase the Mithril founders pack you can pretty much get all of the content currently available. I feel like this game should not cost more than a physical copy for less content, but then again you dont have to play during early access.

The gameplay itself is fun and challenging. Im not planning on looking at decks online so im challenging myself to beat the quests. It actually takes some time people. It doesnt feel like this game is meant to be played more than a couple of hours a day based on the time locked rewards which is confusing, to say the least.

Overall yes this game is worth giving it a chance as long as you understand what you are buying in EA.

author: {'steamid': '76561198361057319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1535555034}
review:
To put it simply, this game is more of a cash grab than a LCG. That's for sure. They promise a free to play game that they then make you pay in order to playtest (which in of itself isnt the worst but it seems the developers don't consider the customer when making a decision). The game as it is, has a lot of issues. I had a scenario where i had to keep a character alive and he killed himself... You have to buy campaign packs regardless of how much you spent on card packs (even the 100 dollar card pack, they still try to bleed you with having to pay 2 dollars here and there).

The game itself is just average. I feel like it doesnt make sense that they make us "playtesters" buy the campaigns when they want feedback. Clearly this game was not thought out or if it was, probably by someone who only wanted the money and didn't care if the game was good or not. The levels can be completed very quickly. It has 3 to 5 quests per scenarios. Sometimes it's incredibly hard and other times it is incredibly easy. It is very unbalanced. Also, many quests can be completed in one round making the scenario that you have to pay 2 dollars for be completed very quickly. Also, if you play the scenario twice, it becomes incredibly easy because you know what to expect.

In order to not pay for other quests, you have to spend valor points. Where, you'd have to grind about 25 quests that you'd also have to have a victory in. Sometimes more depending on how well you play. I don't think anyone would actually want to spend a total time of about 10 hours to earn something that is worth 2 dollars (if it's even worth that). They didn't think this out at all. I know they've got a stream where they played this so they must know these issues but didnt care because they just want those extra 2 dollars from everyone for something that is not nearly worth even the 2 bucks. In my opinion, the first campaign should be free, and perhaps have the next campaign be worth the valor you have to spend on a single scenario like how it is now.

Overall, this was a huge disappointment. Don't buy this please. You'd just encourage this kind of behavior from developers who just want money and not to make a good game. I love LOTR but this just sucks. I will try it again when it is free to play, but as it is now, I don't know if i would play this game if it was the final product. They should have just playtested it and come up with solutions. Heck, I'd do a better job at fixing this game than their team of developers which makes it really obvious that the devolopers are both amateurish and money-grabbing.

3/10 would not play again unless i was paid to

author: {'steamid': '76561198129695038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1282, 'last_played': 1584397980}
review:
Ok I was looking at some of the other reviews and decided to give a review myself.

First things first: If you are looking for a digital version of the 'hard copy' LOTR LCG, then you should wait a few months to see if this game changes drastically from the early access. Other than the name of the game and the names of the cards.....this is nothing like the hard copy game. I don't care who you are...you can not say that this is the same as the hard copy. This has vastly different gameplay and is much easier in my opinion. 

All that being said you need to remember that this is an early access game and is still being reworked. The AI still needs a lot of work done to it, the money system should be reworked, and there are a whole lot of cards not yet added to the system. 

I think that this is either going to be a very long grinding game or P2P game. Right now you start out with some starter cards and one quest for free. Literally everything else costs either valor points or money. You can earn valor points by beating quests, however the quests have a time limit on them so you can not get max points 20 times in one day. It is one time max points every 24hrs. So unless you get multiple quests and have a deck or decks that can get you max points grinding is going to take forever.

I expect that in the future there will be some type of events or sales that if you save up items until then you will get better rewards. So check back when they do updates for this game to see what changes. 

I do recommend this game because of what I think it can be as well as I did not expect the early access game to be the same as buying the core set hard copy. Reviews I read said that they didn't recommend this game because it is nothing like the hard copy. It is and still can be a greatly fun game......with updates.

EDIT: They just announced that the complete first quest cycle will be open for free which is awesome for new players and that they are refunding players who already bought the quests.  From what I can tell Asmodee and FFI are dedicated to making this a great game and I for one am excited to see what they do.

Some things I think need to be addressed are:
1. Some way to more easily know what cards have for specials, ie: Block, Guard, Stalwart - These could be symbols that are added to the picture on the playing field.

2. Why do I have 4 copies of some cards? I can only have 2 in a deck and I can make as many decks as I want with those 2 cards. Possibility of selling excess cards in the future?

author: {'steamid': '76561198032544384', 'num_games_owned': 3268, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1565869303}
review:
[i][b]Note: This is neutral review but with a positive mark now. I do not like the current microtransactions system at all and I think it spoils the game greatly; that is why I cannot write a purely positive review.[/b][/i]

Let us start with a short backstory: when I was a teenager, I used to play a game called Divine Armaments. It was all about collecting cards with cute goddesses and taking them to fast battles against my opponents. Unfortunately, four years later the game was closed due to some unknown reasons (most probably they did not earn as much as they wanted while the game really gave a chance to F2P audience). Anyway, since then I have been looking for a good card game with a smooth gameplay that did not require spending money on it to win. So far, I have been quite unlucky. Has [b]The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game[/b] become my oasis in the desert of pay-to-win titles for whales (people who spend a lot of money on games to gain benefits, if you did not know it already)? Well, it is a tricky question which I am most inclined to answer with *No*.

And just a small side note before we start: I have never played neither the tabletop version of this game nor the Hearthstone. And I am not much of a strategist, to be honest. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1502451811

[h1]Noteworthy features[/h1]

-	The music and voice acting. Both parts are amazing and made the game more alive and interesting;

-	I honestly do not understand why some reviewers say that the game looks ugly. The artwork is very good. Not all the characters look like I have imagined them; but overall, the artists did a great job drawing each picture. The user interface is quite friendly and has lots of interesting parts. I also liked the general feeling of the Middle Earth in each and every detail;

-	And again I do not understand some claims that this is an easy game. Maybe I am not just used to this type of card battles, but I found all quests rather challenging. I managed to fail even the first one quite quickly (not the Tutorial, of course; the first campaign available). I think I will need to ask one of my students for some advice, while he is an avid Hearthstone fan and knows A LOT about proper deck building and stuff like this;

-	The story – you are not mindlessly battling with some unknown enemies. There is complete story that explains what has happened, why you are here, what you need to do, etc. It felt as if I was reading a book along with playing a card game;

-	Gandalf. Just Gandalf who always saves the day.

[h1]Some issues[/h1]

-	Microtransactions. I am 100% sure that all of us hate them. Personally, I am tired of seeing this feature in almost every free-to-play game. Why is it even called a F2P if you in the end you have to pay a lot of money to get all the content? Why not just set a fixed price for the game itself instead? From my own experience, I can say that microtransactions will make you spend more money to purchase what you want than buying a complete AAA-title with way more content. Or you have to grind, for a l-o-ong time.

Still, it is a good thing that The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game is a single player one, so you do not have to compete against other players who do not mind spending hundreds of whatever currency they use on the game. Another nice point is that you can actually buy campaigns, cards, heroes, etc. using in-game currency called Valor. Just keep in mind that you will need to grind to do it. If you do not mind this issue, then microtransactions will not bother you…probably. Oh, and as far as I understood, there are daily tasks that can also bring you useful rewards.

To sum up, there are too many microtransactions to my liking. The only redeeming feature is that you can purchase everything with in-game currency, but it requires a lot of grinding;

-	Sometimes the text was really small and I did not find the way to make it bigger. It was difficult for me to read these parts (which were basically the story ones and some explanations) and I would really appreciate it if the developers could add an option to enlarge the font;

-	It is an early access for now so there are some minor bugs. For example, when choosing to travel after completing a task, I all of a sudden got a message about some error. I did not quite understand what happened, but at least it did not ruin the match or freezed the game. I am sure that developers will address any know issue before the initial release, so I do not think it will cause any problems in the future.

[h1]The End[/h1]

What I would like to see in the final version of the game: first, an option to change the font size – this would help a lot! Second, I think it would be better if instead of microtransactions they added special quests/places where one could get all the cards or some special tasks to unlock new campaigns. This would make the whole collection thing more interesting and engaging than just grinding to get valor.  

All in all, [b]The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game[/b] is not a bad game but not a great one either. There are some issues that need to be addressed first. However, if you decide to overlook them and if you are a big fan of the Middle Earth and the story in general, then you can enjoy what the game offers now. Just be ready for grinding.

For now, I give this game a positive mark but with a neutral grade overall simply because of the amount of purchases you need to make before you get the full game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030895328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1707478493}
review:
I don't really understand the moaners. 
This game is exactly what was on the tin. Yes, I do miss the original LCG but it's completely understood that the developers wanted to make a game that fits more the digital realm than the tabletop one. 
Some artworks are great, the card's are bit below expectations but they may change in the future. They are good enough for Early Access release.
Microtransactions are fine with me, as I can completely avoid them buying the Istari pack. So far, it's challenging, there is a world of possibility for new LOTR rings stories to uncover and I want to go back even when I write this review (spolier alert) to find Bilbo. 

IMO Some people are not happy with anything and they dramatizing it here on a F2P game. Pity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049328656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1704494310}
review:
First off, I would like to say that this is less of a review and more of a rebuff of the negative reviews for this game. Most are simply misinformed and have incorrect grounds. Some common complaints are:

No PVP!   Well, that's one of the points of the game.
Nothing is unlcocked, I have to pay real world money, too many IAPs!   You can unlock everything without spending a penny using valor points (barring your founder's pack, of course).
It's not actually the Card Game!   It's been made quite clear that this is not a one to one port of the physical game.
And finally, just because you personally don't enjoy the gameplay or the reimplementation does not mean the game is subjectively bad.

The visual effects are okay, but the music and presentation are top-notch. The game is extremely new player-friendly. The gameplay is great (in my opinion), and the product format is nearly flawless. In my book, this game helps cement FFG's nigh-on spotless record.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985807945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1658064604}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994963145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1535485199}
review:
https://youtu.be/3J5LPS6PM3s

Je regrette particulièrement l'absence de bouton "OUI/NON".  J'ai du faire un choix entre les deux existants et mon pouce rouge ne reflète pas entièrement ma pensée.  Détails :

Le jeu n'est pas mauvais mais ce n'est pas le Seigneur des Anneaux: JCE.  Ils auraient du changer le nom pour éviter la confusion.  Si le jeu est fonctionnel, il propose désormais une forme Heartstone-like.  On pose les cartes et on frappe.  Si cela n'a rien de déshonnorant comme style de gameplay, il met de côté la richesse que propose la version physique du jeu.  Chacun appréciera en fonction de ses intérêts mais si vous comptiez prolonger l'expérience physique par internet avec vos amis joueurs du JCE, vous serez potentiellement déçu.
Précision pour les joueurs du JCE qui n'ont pas le temps de regarder ma vidéo : 2 phases seulement.  La pioche et la réception de ressources (UPKEEP) et ensuite on tabasse les ennemis ET l'objectif (ADVENTURE).  La différence étant que l'objectif est passif et prend en compte notre volonté et non pas nos points d'attaque.  Trop léger pour ma part.

Une nouveauté sous la forme d'une jauge FATE donnant des bonus a été implémenté.

Personnellement j'ai beaucoup de mal également avec le thème graphique.  Je trouve les cartes héros défigurées par le template très enfantin. 

Nul doute qu'il rencontrera son public, néanmoins.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046589754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1608061226}
review:
Quick review from a fan waiting so long for this one:
I really was after this game since it was announced, and i paid the Gondors Founder pack. After 3 hours of playing i have to admit that its a shame what they have done with the micro-transactions system. There are a lot of successfull free to play games out there that give you the opportunity to enjoy hours and hours and, also, pay for some extra content.

But the paying system of this game is mad, is absolutely insane and no one will accept that. I wanted to pay for the Gondors content and for some more things but is abusive how they force you to pay just to keep playing new content, because the available one is just 30 minutes of playing. Hope they seriously abandon that idea of paying for every step in a campaign, or raise up the amount of valour (the money you can earn playing) so you can pay those new missions with your hours of playing. 

Visuals are pretty beautiful, and, for an old TCG and LCG player mechanics are great, but no way i am going to keep playing with this paying system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041414727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1535526796}
review:
Comme beaucoup, je trouve le système de paiement pour tout dans ce jeu trop abusé. Payer pour débloquer des paquets de carte, ça peut se comprendre, mais payer pour des quêtes ? C'est se moquer du monde.
Dans un jeu de carte PVP, on trouve des adversaires quand on veut sans avoir a payer à chaque fois !
Avoir choisi un modèle PVE, c'est bien, mais devoir payer à chaque fois qu'on veut une nouvelle quête c'est pas possible.
Tant qu'a devoir grind, un système de quêtes générées aléatoirement pour trouver de quoi jouer sans avoir à se taper la même quête en boucle c'est pas compliqué !

Mais si ils comptent faire des sous avec ce système je pense qu'ils se tirent une balle dans le pied.
J'attends de voir leur communication la dessus et comment l'early access va évoluer pour réviser mon jugement.
Ou pas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007020816', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2975, 'last_played': 1596982806}
review:
Let me start with the main issue raised by the naysayers - microtransactions. Yes, there are options to purchase cards, heroes and quests with real world money, but please note that ALL of these are purchasable with the in-game currency that is earned by playing the game, completing missions and completing daily challenges. As the game is in Early Access it would be wrong to judge it by this alone, as it is clear that one will be able to experience all that the game has to offer without spending a cent... and yes, there will be some grind in achieving this, but I can say that with the variety of heroes, quests and deck combinations on offer (which is voluminous even in this stage of early access) it will not feel monotonous.

For an early access game,  this is one of the most polished I have ever played. The quests are varied and interesting (and yes, challenging), the graphics and in-game effects are great, the soundtrack in itself is a work of art and the voice acting is also very good. Not to mention that the heroes and cards provide for very entertaining and varied gameplay opportunities which, as I have said earlier, will lessen the so-called 'grind'.

At writing this review I have played almost 12 hours and have enjoyed every minute of it. Yes, I am a Lord of the Rings fan, so you can take some of what I have said as being biased in favour of the theme. However, from a pure gameplay point of view it is well worth the 'buy-in' for early access and will also help the devs greatly in further polishing this game. Even at this early stage you will be transported to Middle Earth and will feel attached to your heroes and allies, especialy feeling loss when one is killed during battle. So from at least a thematic point of view, this game deserves 10/10.

I wish the devs all the best with the future of this game and hope that it will garnish enough support to enable it to become an epic, longstanding Lord of the Rings title. If you are a fan of the card game genre, fantasy or Lord of the Rings themed games, then you will enjoy this one.

... and if you feel that there is too much 'grinding'... what a better place to grind than in Middle Earth!

Additional comment: Within 72 hours of release the devs made major changes in light of criticism received of some aspects of the game, including removing a time lock for quest rewards, as well as unlocking extra content free of charge (no need to buy with in-game currency or cash). WELL DONE DEVS for listening, you are well on the way of making this a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038262585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1535540463}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976404088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1569660638}
review:
Like many other people I don't understand why they didn't just make this an exact copy of the original card game. Wouldn't that have been easier and quicker than trying to redesign an already awesome game? Why take all this time to make a slightly worse version? It's baffling. They could have even sold it in a similair way to the original, with a core set as an inital purchase, and then the cycle packs as paid addons - exactly as they already are in the physical game (except obviously make them cheaper). I would have happily sunk money into that, Why reinvent the wheel? If they had just done that that i would be 100% onboard. Instead I am about 60% onboard.

Mini rant aside, this is an ok version of the game. I don't feel it is as deep, thoughtful, or rewarding as the game it is based on, but it at least evokes some of the same feel. While it may not have been the game I wanted it to be when it was first announced,  I don't regret buying in at the lowest pack level, and I am sure that  it will become more engaging when there is a larger range of heroes and cards for deckbuilding (which, again, they could have done by now if they had just made the original game). I have still enjoyed it, even with the limited content it currently has.

I'm going to give it a tentative recommendation. It has potential, and I look forward to seeing it grow and improve over time. But your mileage may vary, and I strongly suggest you read other reviews and watch videos of it being played before you decide, as there are aspects of it that may bother you more than they do me.

EDIT: I want to amend this review a bit now that i've had more time with the game. The full first campaign is now available for free to EA buyers, and they are reworking their valor system - neither of which mattered to me, but may be a factor in your decision to get this. For me the issue is that the more I play this the more I realise just how much I prefer the physical version of the game. I'm still keeping my review as a recommendation, as I am sure many people will enjoy the mechanics of the digital one, and because they have never tried to hide the differences between this and the physical version - but, for me personally, this version just isn't as satisfying or rewarding of an experience. It's...fine...but it's jsut not the same. I'll keep an eye on how it develops, and on how quickly the card pool grows, but ultimately I'm always going to wish it was the better version of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027164961', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1602915530}
review:
Most of the complaints are structured about the microtransactions and price walls of the game, rather than. The gameplay itself. 
I find the core game compelling and interesting. 
I feel like I'm the only one that knows this is an early access game? There's things to iron out, and thinking about structuring the microtransactions and reward systems and progression is just one of those things that needs to be tweaked and fixed. 

All in all, so far a great effort! The lore and feel is spot on, which is probably the MOST important thing Lord of the rings fans want :)

This being early access, wait a couple of months to check the progress because at this stage, alot needs to be done but that's not a complaint; it's merely going to take some time like all good games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057937460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1684947525}
review:
PVE hearstone wannabe. Nothing in common with the LOTR LCG. They even stole the card design from HS, together with the LOTR art it looks freaking horrible. HS eggs, HS icons, HS coloring with the LOTR art, fuck you!
The guy who coded the UI must be an ugly person because the UI is super ugly, inconvenient and stupid (just check how UI treats daily rewards).
No content, there is only one miserable campiagn, does it make like 5% or less out the desired content? Usually games in the EA have something to show like 60-70% of content, not 5% lol.
The gameplay is mediocre and it is a compliment.

And the most annoying thing: the game's technical state is abysmal. Lots of gameplay breaking bugs, disconnects, daily quests simply not working. And yes, in a solo game you can't continue your session if the server disconnects you. Start all over again. Thats the stuff I have encountered myself, there is much more from other players.

Only the voicing actors did a nice job, another good thing is my regional pricing, its affordable.

So there are only 2 cons: voicing and regional pricing. Awesome isn't it?

Actually people who had watched streams already knew that the game would be total bullshit.
No surprise, it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032558383', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1589576288}
review:

Somit wird dieses Spiel leider zur Mikrotransaktionsgeldgrab. 

Mechanisch ist es sehr sauber, auch wenn die eigentliche SpielmechaniK nicht so viel mit dem anlogen LCG zu tun hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006897872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1535530404}
review: The game has nothing to do with the boardgame with the same title, so all the people coming to have that boardgame are disappointed, the game doesn't have pvp ofc because is not born with that idea... so everyone from magic heathstone yugioh etc are disappointed. and so far the game doesn't have a coop system. Actually this game is a solitaire with better graphic. Also everything seems walled behind microtransaction (expected)

author: {'steamid': '76561197961527559', 'num_games_owned': 890, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1666135182}
review:
UPDATE: 
     Originally I couldn't recommend this as I felt that the way the game was initially set up was oppressively grindy. FFI Responded quickly to feedback and are planning on unlocking the first full quest line for all players (only 5 quests but that's a good chunk of play and replayability to shoot for the full scores and unlocks). This change goes a very long way towards making the game playable for anyone early, grinding a single quest for valor to try and earn more quests felt like too much, being able to play through a full set of quests is far more reasonable. 

   FFI has also stated that more quest lines should be brought in quickly along with additional character packs and other content, all of which should lend to a lot of good options for people to enjoy the gameplay.  Though I'm still somewhat averse to the style of play vs the original LCG game style it is fairly enjoyable. I do disagree with the cries of "hearthstone clone" etc as the economy of the game plays very differently, I might prefer the paper LCG system but this is still enjoyable and brings about some interesting challenges.
   
 ORIGINAL:
     At this time cannot recommend. The current price structure for unlocks is just awful. With a 15 dollar founder pack you can get 4 total $2 unlocks with the valor you're given, and earning that in game will take an obscene amount of time. This will likely just not work as a free to play structure. 
     A direct port of the paper LCG core box would have been far stronger, a direct port of that rules set would have been stronger and a better game. This is a wierd hearthstone style idea which alters the mechanics much more than it should have, the game was already good, there wasn't a need to deviate so much. I don't understand. I love FFG, when I saw this i was super stoked and immediately picked it up, thoroughly disappointed in the route they took.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039160153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1603654339}
review: Im going to be honest. The style of this game is NOT what I expected. It is primarily single player with plans for co-op in the future. I was thinking this was going to be a competitive card game similar to hearthstone. After a few hours in the game (and getting over complaining how it is not competitive XD) I can say I really enjoy the card game and its mechanics. The story is definitely challenging and you will probably have a few attempts until you defeat the first couple chapters. However, after that the game stops in progression. As Free to play we have to wait to do each mission daily to earn rewards to unlock the next chapter. I am eager to see this game develop and hope to have a lot of content in the future. If you like LOTR Its worth jumping into! The story feels great (what little is out so far in the beta) and definitely a part of the Tolkien world!

author: {'steamid': '76561198135134317', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1603842086}
review:
One of the best single player card game so far. It's an Early Access, don't complain about contents.

BTW the MICROTRANSACTIONS system is a robbery. You get a VP reward after succedeed a quest, but once. Other runs will grant you less points. Shame. 

Do you wanna keep playing? pay 2€
Do you wanna have a chance to win? pay 2€
Do you want a card? Pay for a super convenient 2€ pack of 5 cards.....

You are forced to pay up to 10€ just to achieve the first campaign. OMG

I love the setting, i love the gameplay.....but please....

author: {'steamid': '76561198276696095', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1475, 'last_played': 1604094960}
review:
[i]//edit: in light of the recent changes (mainly the fact that the first campaign is free) I am changing my review to positive. It's not perfect, but there's good will from the developers. Time will tell...[/i]



[b]Digital CCG players that came here for the theme:[/b]
"No Pvp, this is crap, I'm out."

[b]Fans of the tabletop game :[/b]
"This is different from the game I love, why is it different?"
"It looks just like Hearthstone!"
"My god the micro-transactions!"

So who is this game for ultimately? I don't think the developers know either. Maybe they'll figure it out before release.

[b]Personally, I like:[/b]
1. the presentation: art design, soundtrack, narration (leaving aside Gollum and the orcs which are terribly acted), card animations are all very polished. I'm not a fan of the Hearthstone egg-shapes, I wish there was some way to see the full cards on the table without clicking on each one but eh...what can you do.

2. the gameplay: it's actually quite good, if you understand it's not a recreation of the tabletop game. I don't know why people wanted a full adaptation. You can already play everything on your PC anyway...for free! (OCTGN...you're welcome). And who would have bought something like that anyway? Tabletop players who already spent $1000+ on the full collection would not pay $100s to buy the exact same thing in digital form and it's too complicated a game to attract the Hearthstone crowd. Anyway, the gameplay: a bit more random than it could have been (for example, why did they change Sneak Attack to pull a random ally from your deck? now instead of a cool combo you just hope it hits Gandalf instead of a crappy 1-cost ally). But decent overall, if lighter on decisions and planning. Most card games of this type are a bit simplistic before the card pool expands - so I am optimistic that it will get more interesting to deckbuild and play with time. 

3. fixed packs: the fact that I can finally play a digital card game without random boosters that give me the 10th copy of a card which I'll then turn to dust so 3 months later I can buy that card I actually wanted. I applaud this decision!

[b]What I don't like: [/b]
1. the microtransactions: $2 here, $2 there...gosh!. I don't want stuff for free....I just want to pay once and be done with it. Seriously, the way transactions work needs to be reconsidered. It's not 2010 anymore FFI!

2. the structure of heropacks: I appreciate that I can see what I get (see point 3 above) but keeping in line with the LCG philosophy, we should get 2 copies of the cards, not one. Don't make me pay $2 for 4 cards and then pay again for second copies. Yes, I said pay. Because as of now, Valor is so slow to earn that what you get for free is nothing compared to what you get for spending money on the game.

3. [strike]Loot bo[/strike] Erm, Palantirs. You can market and rationalise them all you want, but a loot box is a loot box. And again, you're a decade late to the party if you want to go that route.

[b] In conclusion,[/b]
The gameplay has a lot of potential - enough that I am giving it a positive review, despite my issues with it.
But this is what you get when you pair up a talented, passionate design team with the greediest corporation in tabletop gaming (Asmodee).

author: {'steamid': '76561198014265294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1582768491}
review:
First of all, and probably most important of all : DO NOT GO INTO THIS EXPECTING TO PLAY LOTR LCG.
This game's mechanics are nowhere close to the physical living card game.... Oh, you'll see the same card titles and illustrations, and keywords' names, but that's about it...
This would, for me, warrant a red flag already, because when i put time, and money in something called "The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game" i want to play the lord of the ring living card game.... but hey, in any media transfer, changes are to be expected.... let's keep an open mind...

It is a standard opposition card game with symetrical gameplay but asymetrical cardpools. You and your ennemy each have a different deck (you create yours based on your card.... 3 heroes you will start the game + 30 other cards) and the computer has something in store based on the quest you're attempting but your turns will play the same : collect 3 ressources, draw 2 cards and play one action each until both players pass.

The pros :
 - As its RL counterpart, this game is beautiful ; the cards illustrations and backgrounds wallpapers are really cool-looking, in theme with Middle Earth, and not too much inspired by the movie so they still stand on their own.
 - The music is immersive, whimsical, and has enough different themes so you probably won't be turning it off too soon. I'm pretty much considering buying the soundtrack.
 - The narration at the begining and end of quests and between stages is immersive and well written. It mixes text specific to this game and excerpts of the books, giving a middle earthy feel to the game.
 - The AI, while still being a procedural checklist, has been given thought and doesn't always attack when it wouldn't be smart for it to do so, picks targets somewhat intelligently, and so on.
 - You can pick between 3 difficulties level when you play a game. It changes the number of ressource points your opponent is given on each turn. I would prefer for it to change cards available to the AI or even change its procedures rather than "changing the rules" but hey, can't fault them for giving new players an option to gain experience with the game at a more friendly pace.

The design cons :
 - The UI, while simple and clear enough to understand easily isn't on par with the overal beauty of the illustrations. It's all flashy, ugly color boxes and, to me, break the immersion quite a bit.
 - While it can be considered minor by others, this is really driving me nuts : to see a card details, you need to click it, not to mouse over it. So, to play a card, you have to drag and drop it, you can't click it in your hand then click it where you want to play it.... makes it easy to screw something up...
 - There are no tooltips to explain the keywords of a card, if you want to know what's what you have to hit ESC to open up the game menu and search through a glossary you'll find there. While i do think a glossary is a good idea, tooltips are much more newcomers-friendly.

The gameplay cons :
 - The game is overly simplistic.... it's a watered-down version of any other CCG you can find on your computer with the added twist of playing action per action instead of turn per turn (which, in itself, could be a good idea if the game was better).
 - It is designed to be a PvE game, not a PvP one. Having to play, albeit different quests, against the AI over and over again will end up being a bore because you'll end up catching on to its flaws and will kinda sorta end up being procedural in your plays yourself.
- The tutorial.... There is one, that's a plus, and it takes you by the hand to show you the basics.... but it falls into the trap of showing you everything you have to do until the last turn or two.... It gives you a handle (albeit not very strong) on the mecanics, but not on the decision process...

The elephant in the room :
If you want to play this game with any semblance of seriousness, be prepared to grind yourself to the grave. You are given 1 quest, 4 heroes and 26 cards x2 (and you need 30 cards in your deck, so there are at max 9 cards you won't be putting in your deck to begin with.... sheesh), and 3000 coins (valor points).
- buying 1 new quest is 3750 coins
- buying 1 new hero + 5 cards is 3750 coins
- buying 1 common card is 375
- buying 1 uncommon card is 750
- buying 1 rare card is 1500
the first time each day you complete a quest, you can expect to gain 200/250 coins, subsequent times, you gain less than 1/10th of that amount. MAKE SURE YOU BUY THE QUESTS BEFORE ANYTHING ELSE....
While i understand that a compagny gotta make money off of microtransactions, this is ridiculous.

Overall :
It's free, so check it out, but don't fork money in the game... play once or twice, realize you like middle earth but the game doesn't do it justice, and that you're not prepared to give away your whole life to grind what you'd need for the cards...


I've tried to distance myself as much as possible from the real life LotR LCG to write my review but this is where FFI failed the most in my humble opinion :
The LCG has a large fanbase, and many peoples play it solo, so a computerized version of the game obviously would have a built-in community. Trying to cash in on it isn't, in itself, a bad idea. But, by changing the game mechanics so drastically (and for the worse), you're leaving yourself open to displeasing the fan of the games (which will be the one jumping on it day one and giving the early reviews.... so, might not be the smartest of moves). And calling your product the same as a "board game" we know and love proves you were trying to cash in on it... it's not LoTR digital card game, it's LoTR LCG... Luring us into your microtransacting arms...

I like playing CCGs against a computer rather than live players because i'd rather play RL against living beings, so i'm not minding the PvE aspect of it ; but i've played only a handful of games and i'm bored already.... There isn't much challenge in fighting an AI that will always be the same for a given quest and the grind factor doesn't even allow me the sweet taste of collectionning.

Would the game be drastically different from its RL version, i wouldn't have complained. Unfotunately, this game varies enough from its cousin to bother RL LCG fans and not enough to offer them a new experience.
The RL LCG is perfect for solo / cooperative play because there is no AI involved, the game doesn't make any decision, it's all player based. Every choice you make will impact the resolution of your quest : chosing a card over another, attacking with this ally or defending with this hero, and, of course, enemy cards you reveal. i've played the same quests in RL LCG dozens of times and minute changes in your deck or even in the draw can lead to totally different experiences this would have been perfect for a game that requires you to do the same thing over and over again...

I would even have welcomed some of the changes made for this game.... the guard / range mechanic is interesting and the "pooling" of the ressources does make it easier to understand and less frustrating...

author: {'steamid': '76561198067846380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1605764296}
review: This is a solid start to a digital version of the LOTR LCG. It's still low on content right now, but the same could (and often is) said of the core box for the physical version. It's simplified and streamlined which I think makes sense for a digital version of the game, if you want more complexity in a card game that's what the paper version is there for.  Its definitely going to cost you money if you don't want to grind, but as someone who went in expecting to pay cash for content this doesn't really bother me. I've paid to play the physical game and didn't expect to go free to play for the digital version. I would agree that they're better off giving the first campaign away for free to reduce the flack for microtransactions, but this is still EA so I imagine they're still working though the right balance of free content v purchased content. The scenery of the board is fantastic, I find it adds allot to the immersion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079321788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1449, 'last_played': 1606232265}
review:
I think the mixed reviews clearly stem from the game being in Early Access and not being at full release.  It's true that there are only 5 quests currently and a small pool of cards, however, anyone that is familiar with the Living Card Game model knows this will change drastically over time.  On top of this, the developers have already stated that there will be 2 additional campaign cycles (10 quests total) and 12 new character packs (48 cards + 12 heroes) in the next few months when the game is fully released.  

As for micro-transactions, yes the game has them and yes they're very minor.  We're talking $2 per quest or character pack if you want to unlock them with cash or 3750 valor points (in-game currency).  After unlocking the first 5 quests, I can say that it would be very easy to farm upwards of 1250 - 2000 valor points a day if I wanted to grind the game to unlock everything as quickly as possible.  Being that you can purchase all the cards and unlock all the quests with valor, I don't see  any reason to be upset with the cash option for those who do not want to grind valor points.  There is nothing that is locked behind a pay-wall here, you can play the game however you want.

author: {'steamid': '76561198348355518', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1535526632}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009751968', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1596769591}
review:
I own the board game and it's pretty different. 
Don't buy this digital rendition blindly thinking it's a digital version of the board game. It is not.

That said, the game is really fun to play if you enjoy card games such as heatstone or elder scrolls legends...
 
Some of the board game mechanics are incorporated in a simplified way so you will feel somewhat at home while playing.
Voice acting and soundtrack is top notch! Game content is limited but it just hit early access at the time of my review so give it time! 

Plays well, no crashes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051190935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1541120020}
