author: {'steamid': '76561198009986249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1554661000}
review:
Unless you're heavily invested in LOTR or the paper card game, I'd steer clear for a little bit.

The client is very buggy, and prone to random disconnects and weird lag.

The UI makes the game harder by hiding key details.

Scenario and combat balance feel out of whack.The AI is bad, and the game makes up for it by inflating the stats of the enemies.

And the monetization is not very player friendly right now. Unlocking all the current content takes a good chunk of change as well as a lot of grinding.

But at least all of these things can change during early access! So maybe check back in a month or two.

author: {'steamid': '76561198370795609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1550817965}
review:
This is definitely very different than the physical version, as we were expecting. What I wasn't expecting was a similar price model. IRL $15 gets you one expansion (1 quest and some player cards), in this game the stewards pack ($15) gets you two quests and a couple hero packs. For a video game this is a lot of money, and microtransactions are fairly rampant. I honestly hope they at least get consolidated into expansions similar to the physical game. Paying $15 for a campaign plus cards would feel a lot better than $2 per quest/pack. 

Aside from that I think this is a great game. I absolutely love lord of the rings and being able to play something hearthstone-esque without the competetive aspect and with the lord of the rings theme is absolutely wonderful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052429224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1651668674}
review:
Gioco divertente e ben strutturato.
Le critiche che ho letto (e che non mi aspettavo) derivano dal fatto che non viene considerato l'attuale stato di sviluppo del gioco: è un early access.
I pacchetti e le quest aggiuntive possono essere sbloccate con i punti che si accumulano giocando... un pò alla Hearthstone.
Aspetto l'uscita del coop per poter valutare quello che ritengo sarà l'aspetto più innovativo rispetto a giochi analoghi, in aggiunta al fatto che, per sua natura, è un gioco PvE e non PvP.
E' simile al gioco di carte ma lo ritengo più devertente.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960273557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1603500349}
review: I'm really enjoing it so far, seems like a lot of fun. I've only played the first of the 5 quests, but I worry that I will be looking for more content before it is ready. I don't get the negative response to the cost of the game, especialy those comparing it to the cost of the physical card game. It seems pretty reasonable in comparison to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021053298', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1567271618}
review:
Well this is a surprise! The gameplay looks simple and hearthstone "clonish", but it is not. They have managed to simplify the complexity of the tabletop game and still make you feel like each quest is different and that your tactics need to change in terms of the whole quest and the moment to moment decision making, of which there is a ton BTW. The back and forth as opposed to the whole turns makes it so you really need to be both planning ahead but responding to an ever changing board state. Definetely a much better and challenging game that expected. 

That said, the games has very big problems that need to be fixed before the end of EA and those are :
- Making the grind and the microtransaction structure more clear and more fair. It is just awkward right now and not really F2P. (which i am okay with, just make it easier for people to use cash to acquire most of the game content, ala real life LCGs)
- One fix for this is have hero pack come with playsets of cards instead of just one, right now one feels like being cheated out of money.
- The deckbuilder is basic and horrible, they need to fix this ASAP.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049745394', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1759, 'last_played': 1603029552}
review:
Feel neutral about it. I was expecting an LCG but is not. Still, game is good with some new cards mecanic not seen anywhere. 

Since FFG release the full set of quest for the 1st chapter I change my original review from negative to positive.

FFG, dont call this an LCG it's not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019864374', 'num_games_owned': 633, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1535837103}
review:
It has Lord of the Rings theme and it is designed as a card game, but the structure is completely different than the Lord of the Rings Living card game.   Feels like much of the game design is centered around an exploitative free to play / pay to win model and is much more tactical game than the strategic design that drives the actual card game.  The I go - you go gameplay against an AI opponent feels more a hearthstone ripoff than the Lord of the Rings LCG.  Not necessarily a bad idea, but not something that deserves the Living Card Game label.

Always on connection requirement is also a major downcheck for a game that it currently a single player experiance

author: {'steamid': '76561198054787837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1536166077}
review: Until they improve the disconnect issues and come up with a better free to play model I would not touch this with a ten foot pole.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971317369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1603291469}
review:
I'm fan of the board version and bought every single pack from FFG. Rules of this PC version are not the same as in the board version, they are much simplier. 

One of the biggest issue - dependence on the game servers to play in solo mode. If servers are down or you connection failed, you will be disconnected and lose any current progress of the quest. You can't even play tutorial if you lose your connection.

Economic model is absolutely unfriendly - you've got only one quest (~30 minutes of gameplay) and one player deck available for free, each other quest and deck costs $2 or 3750 Valor points. You get ~200 Valor points for completion of the quest and ~100 for Daily Task, which are not very good (125 points for completion of 3 quests on hard). So you need to grind first quest approximately 30 times with the same deck to buy the next one for Valor points. 

Palantir bonus system is your lootbox - you got randomly two things from: one card, ~200 Valor points, cosmetics.

So actually, it's not free to play game - right now it's absolutely pay-to-play. Board version is much deeper and worth its money. Unfortunately, PC version not worth it yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029480505', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1598579592}
review: Deckbuilding RPG is a good way to describe the game, which is (or will be) co-op. Very worth the price of "free" (having said that, I bought one of the founder's packs). The paid content looks like it can all be earned through game play, or you can toss a couple bucks ($2ish) to speed it up a pace. Good animations and effects already, no real complaints right out the gate. I'm looking forward to burning through the whole first quest — and [i]very[/i] much looking forward to when co-op kicks off!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038791890', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1572156044}

author: {'steamid': '76561198099961731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1536023439}
review: I LOVE the gameplay and the presentation and the questlines and the voice acting. But like almost everyone else is saying, I have essentially purchased somewhere between 2-5 hours (the latter if I'm really, really bad) of content for $8. That simply isn't gonna cut it FFG. So make the first campaign free. Lighten up on the cost of microtransactions, and lets have a community that still gives you plenty of cash and goes nuts for this great game. Until then, I'll just be extremely disappointed that I get content locked so fast due to unrealistic microtransaction cost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007536312', 'num_games_owned': 687, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1594134197}
review:
A lot of reviews claim this is too much like Hearthstone, I'd like to list some many differences since I wholeheartedly disagree with that statement:

* Turn Structure: In Hearthstone you play all your cards, take all your actions and then end your turn. In LotR for every action you take, or card you play, Sauron gets to take an action.
* Resources: In Hearthstone you start with 1 mana and it ramps, no mana carries over. In LotR you get 3 resources a turn and you carry any unused over to the next turn.
* Willpower: In LotR there's a completely unique stat on Characters that allows you to complete quests, defeat hazards, or use Fate effects.
* Varying Objectives: many quests give you more than one way to successfully complete an objective 
* Traveling: During a quest when you complete an objective you travel to the next one, which causes the enemies board state to shift completely while you carry over what you had.
* Branching quests: Many quests give you options when traveling that go to completely different objectives and board states, adding options and replayability depending on your deck or state.
* Fate Events: Fate, mentioned previously, is like another resource that gives access to effects unique to each quest, this could be gaining a unique Ally, one shotting an enemy, changing the objective, etc.
* Threat: Threat is basically a race condition and there's lots of ways it can be manipulated by you or Sauron. It also causes Threat Events which benefit Sauron at certain thresholds.
* Heroes: There are many (or at least will be) Hero combinations you can base your deck off of which also effect which cards you can add to your deck. There's lots of variety in stats and powers of these Heroes.
* Spheres: As mentioned, Heroes each have a sphere, and you need a hero of a cards sphere to add it to your deck, this makes it important to not only choose what hero you like but what sphere they are so you can include certain cards as well.
* Co-op: Not implemented yet but the game will have offline and online co-op so you can play with friends.

Lots of other stuff but this is what comes to mind immediately. So I ask, aside from oval shapes and cards, how is this Hearthstone?

(Comments are on for this review so let me know why you think it is like Hearthstone)

author: {'steamid': '76561198272091149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1540658530}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990526109', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1535493667}
review:
Ive played the regular missions on easy. Got 195 points (3700 to unlock a mission) played it again on normal and lost. Got nothing for losing. Then on normal again and got 95 points because the mission was "time locked" even though I defeated the mission on a harder difficulty. So rewards were way weakened. At that rate no the game is not worth it at all. I would like a semi forseable f2p game.  With these rewards there is no forseable future to the game and it will die pretty quickly.  

Not to say i dont like the mechanics or the graphics or the voice overs. All that is amazing. The grind....not so much. I think personally ima ask for a refund until they fix the game. 

They need to have 4-5 missions for new players to grind out. And a reward even for losing.

 Math has it if i get say ..... 200 points per win. Takes me 10 mins per mission. Would take 3.33 hours of grinding the same exact mission to get enough points to buy a new one. And thats if and only if i dont lose. To me thats a bit much. But i guess thats f2p aspects.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968817939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1595711756}
review:
Let me preface this by saying I was absolutely delighted when the news first broke that Lord of the Rings LCG was coming to digital.  As someone who loves the paper card game I was really looking forward to a digital version that would save me the trouble of set-up and tear down time.  Unfortunately, as time went by I realised that the vision for this version of the game strayed further and further from the original.  Regardless, I still wanted to give it a go and so I bought the top tear version of the game to support FFG and show there is desire for these games in digital format.

Now, after playing through the tutorial, the first 2 quests and unfortunately being kicked off the server during the 3rd quest I can say that, upto this point, this digital version shows none of the invention of the paper game.  Each turn of the paper game is a puzzle of weighing up risks and strategies, daring to quest or conserving actions for potential encounters in a later round.  Each quest in the paper game is unique in its own right with clever innovations that alters the gameplay and keeps the game feeling fresh.  The paper game is really beautifully realised.  Disappointingly, the digital version lacks the innovation that keeps the paper game so fresh and interesting.  Up to the point I have played it feels as though each phase of each quest is simply a fight to the death with little tactics or strategy.  Indeed I have had no trouble finishing quests with the starter deck and have given little throught to the actions I've taken during each game.  This really is a distilled version of the paper game - and actually, I'm not even sure it can be called a version of the paper game at all.

Furthermore, there are other problems with the game.  The presentation of the board and menus are fine, but the cards themselves are poorly considered.  The frames crowd out the beautiful art from the paper game and the characters jump into action with clear appropriation from Hearthstone.  

There is no tracking of stats in the game currently, no way to see which quests you've defeated and what scores you've acheived.

The upside of this all is that this is still an early access game and perhaps more invention will come in the future.  However, the foundations look like they've been laid down and there doesn't appear to be anywhere near the complexity, depth or difficulty of the original game.  

It's a shame.  I wish this was a faithful recreation of the original so that more people could experience its brilliance - but I can't currently recommend this digital version.  I will persevere and will revisit this review if my opinion changes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030761641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 56782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1969, 'last_played': 1592408109}
review: I really have enjoyed the initial 2 quests and story lines within the Shadow's Reach early access campagin.  I've been following FFI's twitch steam since I heard about the game a couple of months ago and I am really excited about this awesome board game coming to digital.  It is not a 1:1 copy of the board game but the synergies are totally worth experiencing.  I look forward to where FFI will be taking this game as we stress test it out in early acces and provide feedback to them.  Great job on your initial offering FFI!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025955658', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1577037625}
review:
Edit Dec 2019:

They've just made quite a bit of content free, which moves this into a buy recommendation. It's not as good as the paper game, but it is a fun diversion.

Edit Aug 31:

[b]Timers are now gone, and there's more content included in the initial purchase. Good responsive signs from the developer. Still not what it could be (yet), but very close. Just needs more than one campaign, a bit more difficulty and AI adjustments, and more polish.[/b]


[strike] Unfortunately there's a fair amount of microtransactions, a huge grind with timers, and a small amount of content - one campaign at the time of review. Basically, everything you'd expect in an early access card game. [/strike]

[strike] Still, the few scenarios are fun for the first run-through or two, if you are able to unlock any. [/strike] If you are willing to pay $8 for a couple hours of playtime, then this may be worth it. The core gameplay loop is good, but a bit easy if you've played any sort of card game similar to this. I was able to finish off each quest on hard mode with just the intro cards, so there's not a long-term challenge here.

I'm willing to forgive the poor and predictable AI and the large list of bugs I encountered, as it's day 1 of early access, but will be hoping for more fixes in the future.

I'm hoping that the game has a future, but it will take some refining of the AI and additional content to guarantee that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000216029', 'num_games_owned': 1391, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1549764955}
review:
As a fan of the LCG, I've been eagerly waiting for this game to come out. I picked up the Shire Founder's Pack as a reference to where I'm entering the game at.

The game is completely different from the LCG. Phases are gone, questing is different, hero's spheres have a different significance, and the encounter deck is replaced by Sauron playing cards against you. 

It's similar enough yet different enough that I want to have both in my collection, because I think this can be a great game in the long term. The game pauses occasionally after taking an action, but is otherwise smooth.

I believe the rewards are a little lacking, as is the size of the card pool at the moment. It seems like it will take quite a while to actually earn all of what is currently in the game when you start with minimal Valor points, and I think this is a bit of a double-edged sword. It might work if there were more options from the start, but with such a limited pool to begin with, it could cripple players' interests if updates don't come soon enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043080164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 2881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1606347129}
review:
[review edited after recent patch]

- It's not exactly like the cardgame: they just use the art and watered down some mechanics of it
+ Presentation is really solid (apart from some voice-acting like Gandalf, who sounds ridiculous)

Playing this for some hours gave me some enjoyment, but it's not even close to the LCG. That being said, it's not a "Heartstone" clone as some people claim, though it borrows some mechanics. The art and atmosphere are great and the monetization has been toned down somewhat days after the release, making the 8$ package actually an option. You start with some money to buy the cards you want but will have to unlock the rest by gameplay and reasonable daily quests.

EDIT: These negative points have largely been resolved atm so I'm deleting them from the review:
- Lots of server issues so far
- Rubs the monetization in your face through quite frankly all its menus
- Heavily restricts daily rewards
- You actually have to pay 8$ minimum and get far less content than even the greediest F2P cardgame to start with

author: {'steamid': '76561198003122918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1304, 'last_played': 1694260097}
review:
not that bad, but to expensive for what it is at the moment. 
still believe in this game, but they should offer the scenario's for free imo. 
also random loot drop from palantir is weird. 
paying for a booster pack grants you a palantir view which gives you random loot, could be a card you do not have in your collection yet or only once and a new avatar, or some valor points... i'm not a fan of this.
the game itself is good, and plays different then lcg. the voices are fun and coolest part of the game. overall i rate it atm a 6 /10 but it's still early access perhaps they change some stuff in the next weeks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042430595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1595718127}
review:
Mein erster Eindruck als Spieler der physischen Variante von FFG, sowie meine Sicht auf den CashShop und die Mikrotransaktionen. Ganz unten das Kurzfazit für alle die sich die Masse an Text nicht antun wollen.

Wer von dem originalen Kartenspiel kommt wird Artworks und den generellen Flair wiedererkennen. Dieser wurde sehr gut getroffen.
Das Gameplay wurde allerdings drastisch verändert. Zwar spielt man immernoch "PvE" gegen das Spiel selbst, also nicht PvP wie es hier lustigerweise auch in den Reviews immer wieder eingefordert wird, sowie in der generell selben Struktur wie in der Vorlage von FFG (Thread Meter, Orte erkunden, Monster schnetzeln, mehrstufige Quest erfüllen). Hier hört die Ähnlichkeit dann aber auch schon auf.

Die wohl größte und meiner Ansicht nach gewagteste Änderung ist die Einführung eines KI Gegners (Sauron) der abwechselnd mit dem Spieler spielt. Auf jede Aktion des Spielers führt Sauron eine Gegenaktion aus. Dabei entsteht ein sehr großer Zufallsfaktor (meine größte Kritik an dem Spiel).
Natürlich gab es auch schon in dem originalen Kartenspiel einen zusätlichen Zufallsfaktor durch das hinzufügen der Schattenkarten an Monster. Trotzdem hatte man dort deutlich mehr optionen darauf zu reagieren und das Spiel selbst in die Hand zu nehmen. Vielleicht fehlt hier aber auch einfach nur die Menge an Karten um entsprechende Optionen zu bieten.

Zwischenfazit: Das Gameplay an sich unterscheidet sich vom Gefühl her stark von der physischen Vorlage. Manches wurde gut umgesetzt manches fühlt sich komisch an. Für viele Veteranen wird es sehr schwer sein die gewohnten Vorgänge so über den Haufen geworfen zu sehen. Letztendlich kann es aber nur jeder für sich selbst entscheiden ob ihm das hier gebotene Gameplay liegt oder nicht.

Dann der Cashshop - Großes Streitthema wie man momentan anhand der vielen Diskussionen und der Reviews sehen kann. Preislich orientiert sich das Spiel hier an seiner Vorlage. Eine neue Quest kostet 3750 Punkte was in 2€ übersetzt wird.
Desweiteren kann man sich alle nicht im Core Set enthaltenen Karten ebenfalls mit der Ingame Währung kaufen. Je nach "Rarität" der Karte für 375, 750, 1500 oder 3000 Punkte. Dabei muss theoretisch jede Karte zweimal gekauft werden um die maximale Anzahl für das Deck zu erhalten.
Was enthält nun eine normale Erweiterung der physichen Version von FFG (Hierbei spreche ich von den kleineren Erweiterungen der Zyklen)

IdR 60 Karten.
Darin enthalten: 
1 Quest
entsprechende Karten für die Quest
1 Held
9 Karten (x4 um das Decklimit zu erreichen)
Diese werden bei Amazon zwischen 12 und 16€ angeboten.

Setzen wir das hier um ergibt das:
1Quest 3750P
1Held ???
9Karten 3 für 375, 3 für 750, 2 für 1500, 1 für 3000 (x2 um das Decklimit zu erreichen macht 22500P also ca. 12€)

Man bekommt aber keine physischen Karten dafür sondern nur einen digitalen Zugang. Dafür erscheint der Preis doch wieder recht hoch. Großes Aber: Man kann sich die Punkte auch durch reines Spielen erfarmen. Der Grind dafür ist hoch, Quests müssen zigfach gespielt werden. Ehrlich gesagt hat das für mich aber stets den größten Reiz beim original gemacht. Verschiedene Decks und Strategien gegen bekannte Gegner zu schicken. Die Belohnungen könnten trotzdem gefühlt etwas größer ausfallen. Lösungsansätze dafür wurden bereits mehrfach gepostet.
Wer sich mit dem Grind nicht anfreunden kann und trotzdem alles umsonst haben möchte für den ist das Spiel definitiv nichts.
Verglichen mit dem Vorbild von FFG finde ich die Preise aber durchaus fair gesetzt.

Technik:
Für einen EA läuft das Spiel bei mir wider Erwarten erstunlich rund. Einiges wirkt noch unfertig oder improvisatorisch, der Content fällt recht schmal aus, aber das Spiel fängt ja auch gerade erst an. Das Original hatte damals schließlich auch nur ganze 3! Quests.
Ich hoffe dass das Team dranbleibt und jetzt in regelmäßigen Abständen Verbesserungen und Content anbietet.

Fazit: Es wird hier ein rundes Spiel abgeliefert, dass jedoch eher für sich alleine stehen sollte. Inspiration wurde natürlich offensichtlich am bekannten Vorbild von FFG geholt, jedoch so sehr verändert, dass es gerade für Veteranen doch sehr gewöhnungsbedürftig ist. Die Mechaniken funktionieren an sich aber gut, die Tiefe an Möglichkeiten ist aber gerade wegen der wenigen bisher vorhandenen Karten recht begrenzt.
Die Einführung eines KI gesteuerten Sauron als Gegenspieler halte ich für die gewagteste Neuerung.
Die Mikrotransaktionen sind für viele Spieler ein großes Problem. SIe orientieren sich stark an den Preisen des Originals, allerdings erhält man hier keinen physischen Content, was die schon im Original recht hohen Preise verschlimmert. Allerdings kann man dagegenhalten dass sich der Komplette Content (mit viel Grind) komplett kostenlos erspielen lässt.

Insgesamt kann ich das Spiel unter Vorbehalt sowohl für Veteranen als auch Neueinsteiger die ein spannendes Story lastiges Coop, PvE Kartenspiel suchen empfehlen. (Achtung! Zwei Spieler Coop wird erst im Laufe des EA eingeführt werden).
Wer allerdings Zweifel hegt, ob ihm die Neuerungen und Veränderungen liegen oder den Spaß rauben dem ist zu empfehlen auf den Free to Play Release zu warten und sich dann ein Bild des Spiels zu machen.

Das Spiel hat aber einen einigermaßen sauberen Start hingelegt und muss jetzt nur noch einen guten weiteren Weg einschlagen.

Update: 
- Die erspielbaren Punkte wurden stark erhöht. Das Wiederholen von Quests bringt jetzt stets die volle Belohnung anstatt nach dem ersten Mal für 12 Stunden reduziert zu werden. 

- Die komplette erste Kampagne wurde für alle Spieler kostenlos freigeschaltet.

(Auf Spieler Feedback wird hier anscheinend gehört :) )

author: {'steamid': '76561198018373876', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1668852689}
review: Really loved it! Brutally hard, great atmosphere and artwork. I love the roleplay elements too. While some may balk at the microtransactions, it's far less of a financial commitment than something like HS, and also the PVE is fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031534681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1585004746}
review:
This is the first time I've ever gotten into an early access game, and I definitely and doing so a little weary of the consequences of forking over money before seeing the finished product. I purchased the $48 bundle becauseI am a huge fan of the original LCG and I have had my eye on this since the day it was announced. If you are willing to pay the money, then there is a decent amount of content you can get off the bat between the "core game" and the missions you can get with the coins from the bundle. I now have all of the extra available heroes and missions and I have a decent chunk of points left for future updates. However, it is apparent to me that these coins won't get me much more than one more set of 5 missions and possibly a new hero or two. I can definitely see this game becomming a bit of a money pit if there isn't a reasonable enough grind rate for earning the coins in game.

That being said, the game itself I found to be rather enjoyable, and over two hours I've only dabbled with a few playthroughs of the first of 5 missions in order to get my feet wet with a few different decks. The game is NOT the same as the physical LCG so be aware of that. It does keep quite a few of the interesting concepts from the original game though, and it is definitely more complex than a "co-op heathstone" like it might appear to be in the trailers. I'd rate my initial experience as a solid 7/10 and I look forward to seeing how easy it will be to acquire future content without needing to dip in much further than the initial $48 finanically. For now, this gets a thumbs up from me, but that could change depending on the weeks leading up until the full realease.

Edit: Seeing as the developers refunded all the Valor spent on unloocking the first campaign and having completed the campaign and revieved some in game rewards, I can now affirm that the monitization of this game is not going nearly as poorly as I and a lot of others have feared. I now have unlocked every character pack and story mission, as well as over half of the Valor cards with Palantir Views, and I still have over 40,000 Valor points available to purchase new character packs and missions as they come out. It seems like there will be plenty of content to unlock with the $48 bundle I purchased, and I feel as if I am gaining Valor points quickly enough to stay ahead of having to sink more money in for quite some time.

Overall, the game is a fun, new take on the digital CCG genre and I look forward to seeing where the developers go with subsequent characters and missions. I am happy to maintain my positive recommendation after this first week of play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003168389', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1289, 'last_played': 1668458156}
review:
I'm a very big fan of the tabletop version of the game and card games in general. Be aware, digital version is not 1:1 copy of board game! There is a lot of things I like - graphics, sound, guard mechanic. Some things needs more polish - UI, tutorial.....but the game as a whole WORKS very well.

I can see a LOT! of potencial in this game and in this collectible singleplayer card game format as well. I hope this game will have bright future, because I had such a blast playing LOTR Card Game.

Devs, please be quick with your updates, I can't wait more content. :))

author: {'steamid': '76561197980104420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1535487951}
review:
It's a good PvE card game with interesting gameplay in a universe that I love. Outside of the card gameplay (a bit like Hearthstone) It's focused on lore and storytelling.

BUT why being so aggressive with the microtransactions? Within a campaign you have quests, and each quest is about 30 min and costs $2 or about 3750 VP (valor points, the game's currency). Now if you win a quest of course you get a fair amount of VP, but wait, there is a cooldown on earning VP because if you farm this same quest (even if you get a better score) you will get about 20ish VP per win until the cooldown is over (from what I read on the forums 12h). Do the maths... it's an insane grind or take out your wallets.

So you make a PvE game, all right, I don't mind buying packs or farming for packs to beat higher difficulties, but this is stopping the campaign progression. Right now I'm stuck playing the two first quests over and over again getting close to nothing in game currency earnings. 

Who thought this was a good idea? If this is a game based on lore and storytelling, who in their right mind would like to do the same quest dozens of time reading the same story over and over again?

I hope this will change because the game has potential.

*also note while it's PvE you need an internet connection. If you get disconnected from the sever you will loose your quest progress. It happened to me once. I'm hopeful they will fix it soon and might add an auto save feature.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971652076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1578453636}
review: I'm with many of the others here. I have invested heavily in the physical LoTR LCG, and I know this is intended to be different, but the immediate and up-front microtransactions are a real eye-opener, even for somebody who has spent $14.95 a pack over the course of so many physical packs over the years.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987652135', 'num_games_owned': 366, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1602950721}
review: Amazing card game, really challenging, I like it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016000624', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1630330406}
review: Super fun. They've taken a lot of modern game design philosophies and have applied it to the tabletop game. Removing distinct phases reduces downtime, and the back and forth action creates a lot more decision points than just playing out all your cards in a single phase (like you do in the tabletop game). The quests are quite varied, and with multiple stages, quite long to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002118697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 696, 'last_played': 1603835538}
review: I'm a huge fan of the original card game this is based on. Obviously, this is an adapatation so many things are different, but it is super enjoyable so far. The gameplay essentially consists of trading actions (including playing cards) between yourself and the Sauron AI, and this leads to a lot of interesting decision points and places where skill can play a part. Looking forward to the future!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013544965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 926, 'last_played': 1605604361}
review:
He jugado dos partidas, y la verdad es que es bastante entretenido, tengo el juego de cartas y bueno es una experiencia distinta, a mi personalmente  me ha gustado, y creo que le dare una oportunidad aunque no se puede comparar con el de cartas original no esta mal y tiene un amplio margen de mejora.

Funciona de la siguiente manera, eliges tres heroes, creas un mazo de 30 cartas y juegas la campaña, que esta compuesta por misiones y cada una de ellas por varios actos, en los cuales te enfrentas a cartas de enemigo, lugares, o eventos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017350843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1586854415}
review:
Главный недостаток игры в настоящий момент - стоимость новых квестов. При выполении квеста вы получаете около 200 Valor Points (VP)(на сложности Easy, на Normal и Hard количество VP может отличаться), каждый новый квест стоит 3750 VP. Следовательно, каждый квест придется переигрывать десятки раз. Дейлики не спасают - за выполнение вы получите смешное количество VP (в моем случае награда за дейлик была 90 VP).
Буду надеяться, что к релизу это подкорректируют.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006965288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1567838339}
review:
Seriously fun, it's reminiscent of the original game in all the right ways, while having new spins on things. Current things to watch out for in early access: Slow grind, possible crashes. Game's super good so far though, and even with just a single quest you'll have quite a bit of entertainment goin' for ya. No co-op at this point, but it's guaranteed to be added.

Also, people get mad for no reason that this game doesn't have PvP which is hilarious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042198830', 'num_games_owned': 1848, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1540364341}
review:
Long Story Short: Great foundation, not a lot of content right now, revenue structure seems off.

Quick review: After playing for a couple of hours so far after purchasing the Shire Pack I really enjoyed the short time I had with what they offer so far. I love the franchise it's based off of and there is a lot of fun strategy deck building to be had here, but at the moment there really isn't much to do after the first inital couple of quest. Even though this is not a PVP game there will be hours upon hours of grinding the same mission again to earn in game currency to unlock cards and quests.(Which are the main souce of content for this game) I can understand this is early access but I really don't see anymore enjoying this for the long haul right now. I'll keep a close look at this game and update this accordingly! Please check out my playthrough of the tutorial for even more information 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UrUtPEz4GS4

author: {'steamid': '76561198008831578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1565793193}
review:
I played the physical Card game extensively so I've been waiting for this but the Micro Transactions will kill you. I'll keep it in my collection to see what happens but no way am I going to spend the kind of money you would need to get all the content. Grinding your way through the same content over and over again to get a few Valour every time would take you days just to get enough Valour to get somewhere.
Really hope they drop the prices of the content or seriously up the Valour you get for completing missions.

I've played Hearthstone for years and never spent a cent so I don't mind a bit of grinding but this is ridiculous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073189777', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1542992621}
review:
[b]The Lord of the Rings Living Card Game[/b] hat erst einmal einen unglaublich langen Namen. ^^
Generell ist es allerdings ein digitales, story-driven Kartenspiel, heißt es gibt kein Ranked und kein PvP. Stattdessen hat man verschiedene PvE Quests, die man alleine und in naher Zukunft auch im Coop bestreiten kann.
Das Spiel soll nach dem Early Access komplett Free to Play werden. Mit der erspielbaren Währung kann man sowohl neue Karten, wie auch neue Quests freischalten.

[h1]Positiv[/h1]
- Sehr gute, vertonte Geschichte zu den Quests
- Viele bekannte Helden/Orte aus Herr der Ringe
- Einzigartige Kartenspiel Mechaniken

[h1]Negativ[/h1]
- Ausmaß des "Grindings" (statt Zahlens) noch nicht ganz erkennbar
- Relativ wenig Inhalt für den Anfang (5 Quests zum Start)
- Extra Konto-Anmeldung auf einer Webseite


Das Spiel startet mit einem Tutorial in dem uns einige Mechaniken des Spiels erklärt werden. 
Danach muss man sich erst einmal auf einer Webseite anmelden, sonst geht es nicht mehr weiter im Spiel... 
Daraufhin erhält man sein erstes Starterdeck mit einigen Startkarten und die erste Questreihe.
Es gibt Heldenkarten (z.B. Aragorn) und Allierte (Kreaturen, Gondor-Soldaten, etc.), Ausrüstungsgegenstände für die Helden (z.B. Bilbos Schwert Stich), sowie Vorbereitungskarten, die wie Fallenkarten wirken können. Der Gegner ist normalerweise Sauron, der je nach Quest einem andere düstere Wesen (z.B. Spinnen, Orks, etc.) entgegen stellt. 
Besonders hervorhebenswert ist die qualitativ hochwertige Erzählweise der Quests. Normalerweise wird eine richtige Geschichte in englisch erzählt, wie anfangs zum Beispiel eine Reise von Bilbo mit einigen Zwergen (bekannt aus dem Hobbit), welche in einer Kampfsituation enden, in der wir dann spielen und ein bestimmtes Questziel erreichen müssen. Questziele sind wie Kreaturen auf der Gegnerseite und müssen ebenfalls besiegt werden, während uns Sauron immer mehr Gegner entgegen schleudert. Ab und zu taucht auch ein Nebenziel auf, dass den Kampf solange beeinflusst bis wir es vom Spielfeld gefegt haben.

Nachdem Hex: Shards of Fate in Sachen PvE die Fans enttäuscht hat, habe ich bei diesem Spiel die Hoffnung, dass es ein gutes Kartenspiel mit guter Geschichte wird ohne kompetitiven Druck zu beinhalten. Für alle die einfach gern ein Kartenspiel aus Spaß spielen ist das Spiel, meiner Meinung nach, auf jeden Fall einen Blick wert.

Falls Ihr einen visuellen Eindruck vom Spiel wünscht, könnt Ihr gerne im Video unten meine ersten Erfahrungen (das Tutorial) in diesem Spiel miterleben.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jvk8wswAaDQ

author: {'steamid': '76561197969273227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 3876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2830, 'last_played': 1604243094}
review:
Description: An abandoned experiment based on a successful physical predecessor. A unique PVE-orientied and story-heavy card-based adventure in the beloved LOTR universe. Shallow in contrast to the original physical card game, with a lacking AI and a dumped down game mechanic.

Pros (+)
+ Great writing during the short story-pieces set between the gameplay bits
+ Immersive game board design
+ Distinct playstyle between the different deck types / archetypes / spheres.
+ The whole game is playable in coop which is listed as a "pro" here, because it is a rare feature in card-battle games

Neutral (>)
> LOTR universe
> Card visuals are taken off the physcial card game (They are beautiful!)
> Solid tutorial
> The game shifted away from the original unique and challenging "phase-based" mechanics of the physical cardgame to a stuttering 1action-per-turn mechanic which feels different but worse

Negative (-)
- The game got abandoned really fast after release (!!!)
- The AI does not work well and with a proper decision making
- Horrible cardframe design which trys to imitiate something like hearthstone instead of sticking to it's own beautiful physical predecessor
- Bad communication by the developers. There is still no offical announcements that the gamestudio got closed

Overall: It is a shame that the game got changed to much in regards to its awesome physical predecessor in terms of gameplay, frame design and ruleset. The AI is not able to deliver a sufficient gameplay experience. But the game got abandoned quick anyway so I can only recommend picking the game up during a steam-sale/discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044712754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1535501436}
review:
I've gotten a taste for the game after playing through the tutorial and beating the game on Normal in Early Access.

It's good. I like the combination of adventure game/card game. I have no experience with the tabletop game and I might give it a shot after this. I'm not thrilled about the Free to Play elements, I'll be honest, but could be a good time sink for the casual player.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992787604', 'num_games_owned': 1501, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 5796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1178, 'last_played': 1671627127}
review:
EDIT: I HAVE CHANGED MY REVIEW FROM NEGATIVE TO POSITIVE.. ARCHIVING OLD REVIEW UNDER THE LINE. NEW REVIEW FOLLOWS:

LotR LCG is not a direct translation from the paper tcg. This is unfortunate. The game isn't complex nor amazing, but it's presented well, has decent replay value and is pretty fun. The AI isn't very smart and I'm worried it'll get worse once we have more cards. There's not a lot of content right now. I've scored 275/275 on every mission on hard for every character and unlocked everything all in under 10 hours of play. They are working on and fixing the micro-transaction model so that helps a ton. All in all, worth checking out for the first campaign once it goes free to play and definitely will be more interesting when we get more deckbuilding options.

---------------------
Played through the first mission. The gameplay is fine. There's not much new being done here. It's polished, looks pretty, and well voice acted. You finish the tutorial and the first campaign with the starter deck and then you see...

Holy god the microtransactions. Every single mission (5 in a campaign) costs $2. Every single "hero pack" costs $2 (5 cards in a hero pack). If you want additional cards.. well, those cost more money per card. You can buy the $48 founder's pack and $18 of it disappears to just to get the 4 currently available hero packs and 5 mission unlocks. Not to mention when the other campaigns unlock or they add more hero packs, or if you want specific cards for your deck. And this is a single-player only game. There's no competition except against the AI. I'm not sure I've ever seen microtransactions like this in a single player game outside of some predatory mobile clients.

They have a "random reward" option via a palantir but it feels pretty lootboxy.

Man, I love FFG, and I was excited to stumble across this today. But this is a huge black strike in my book. I love the LotR LCG, but this is not the LCG (or anything close). It's massively stripped down of mechanics and feels like a license/nostalgia cash grab.

I had bought the $50 pack. I thought this was going to be awesome. It's not. Filed for a refund.

(EDIT: I want to add an additional thought. I love the LotR LCG. I still play it all the time. I see people here on the forums saying this digital version is "basically the same". It's not. The paper LCG is deep and challenging, deck building is interesting and complex. The gameplay requires careful planning and tons of decisions to make. The missions brutal and epic. This is a shallow puddle of a back-and-forth "attack or play a card" yawngame that isn't remotely like the paper LCG and literally does nothing new or interesting.)

(EDIT 2: Ok. I love FFG so I didn't do a refund. Instead I played through all of the content. I unlocked 2x all of the cards and I perfected every mission on hard. I exhausted the limited deck-builder options as there aren't many cards. And I did this all in... 6.7 hours. 

The AI is pants-on-head stupid. The scoring system (which feeds into the currency) is designed so that you actually don't want often to complete the objectives "correctly" (also, you get the same scores whether or not you play on easy or hard). Some cards are super unbalanced (seriously, put Legolas in every deck. Also, Erkenbrand with weapons just slaughters the AI) and some cards are completely useless (like the 50 threat card). 

Fun fact.. if you in-game currency unlock 2x all the commons/uncommons then the Palantir has to give you rares and legendaries. 

I just wanted a digital version of my favorite solo/coop card game and I got this instead. I love you FFG, I support you FFG. The actual implementation of this game (outside of the AI, which is always hard to code) is well done, it's just the game that isn't very interesting or hard.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993622243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1535476346}
review: You only get 1 quest (30 min of gameplay) for free. With the Shire Pack (and registering your account) you get enough points to buy two more quests for a grand total of 1.5 hours of gameplay for 8 euros. If you want more each quest is 2 euros or 10 hours of grinding the same few early quests to earn the points in the game.
